reviewText:
Way to ♥♥♥♥ up your sequel Crytek. Honestly, I blame EA more for it but still. The original Crysis had complex sandbox missions with multiple approaches and secondary objectives and plenty of bad ♥♥♥ suit powers. Crysis had an enjoyable cast of characters that I actually cared about. Crysis had varied vehicles, all of which were drive/flyable, Crysis had BLUE aliens that froze things. Crysis had a unique blend of strategic, tactical, intense, fun combat. Crysis had an original and interesting multiplayer.

This is not Crysis. This is Call of Halofield 7: Future Warfare. They traded in EVERY SINGLE THING that made the first game great. Whether it's the linear as all hell story missions, the characters that were one-dimensional, cliche and predictable to the end, the dumbed-down nanosuit that somehow manages to feel less powerful than the marines you fight with, the HORRENDOUS checkpoint system, the aliens that are the exact opposite of the first game's, the lack of Psycho's presence, the removal of the ability to carry two primary weapons AND pistols AND use your fists (in fact, fists are completely gone), you can only use humvees/APCs instead of, oh, I don't know, TANKS and VTOLS and HELICOPTERS and other awesome ♥♥♥♥, the bland/generic EVERYTHING, the multiplayer that is a complete rip-off of Call of Duty (and is now full of hackers that nobody does anything about), the list goes on.

Anyways, the point is DON'T BUY THIS GAME. It is an insult to the original and in fact an insult to games in general.

reviewText:
Crysis 2, like the original is a first person shooter. The game was released in early 2011. It also follows on from the plot of Crysis 1 as well. Although you don't really need to have played the original in order to follow the story. Crysis 2 was also the first game to use the CryEngine 3.

The game play has all of the regular FPS style features. You play the role of a Recon Marine, called Alcatraz. You are able to customize your weapons to match the situations you are in, as well as customizing your suite to the same too. Crysis 2 is set in New York City, which is often referred to by many as an urban jungle. This does however offer various different tactical options when it comes to planning attacks; allowing players to navigate between floors and buildings, and ruined buildings.

We also see a few changes in the Nanosuit used by our character too; this time you are able to use more than one suit power at a time, the strength and power modes have been combined into the same mode, and the stealth suit has been improved slightly.

Crysis 2 has AMAZING graphics; this could easily pass as a game being released recently. If you put all of your settings up to full, you are going to be in amazement at how good this game looks. You will need a beefy rig to keep a steady 60 fps, but my oh my it is worth it.

I sadly see no replay-ability in Crysis 2, there are the addition of a couple of difficulty modes, but to be honest; once you have played it the once, there is no reason to play it again. The single-player campaign is a decent length though - we are looking at a 18 hour long story mode which is very good for an FPS.

Thankfully I had no technical issues with Crysis 2 (unlike I did have with the original), I was able to play with every graphical setting on ultra and still had 60 frames the whole time. The only thing I will mention is there is no longer any multiplayer support since GameSpy shut it's servers down in May 2014.

If you enjoyed the first Crysis game, you will basically enjoy Crysis 2, it's the same just with even better graphics, more compelling story, and stellar FPS action and did I mention the amazing graphics? People may think £20 is a bit steep for a game of this age, however I am completely happy with this price as it almost fits into the £1/hour ratio.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText: If you've played a FPS in the last few years - then what Crysis 2 has to offer should not be mind blowing. Machine Guns, alien swarms, sniper rifles, grenades, headshots, shotguns, etc. Shoot a red barrel and it'll explode...yeah, it's all there. Personally, I would describe myself as quite over" the FPS genre as a whole. However
date: that being said Crysis 2 manages to do all the typical FPS shooter mechanics extremely well... and throws in a couple of unique (although still not exactly not mind-blowing) little tweaks which is what makes this a really great game
recommended:
and subsequently worth your time and money.

First off the single player campaign is both lengthy and well paced. The story (I have not played the original) is solid for the archetypical "Stop The Alien Scourge" type of deal. Coupled with really tight controls and a good swatch of weapons - it makes for a rewarding experience. The whole differentiator for the Crysis series is the suit that you are in control of. You can enter two modes which change the way you face each challenge. Being able to go "Stealth" (vis 'a vis the Predator effect) means that you can approach enemies unseen. Upgrades to your suit eventually allow you to perform more stealth kills and even walk through crowds of enemies unseen.

The second mode is an Armored mode. This basically allows you to go whole hog for a time and survive for a couple of hits longer then you normally would in a firefight. Doesn't make you invincible but it gives you a definite edge in both taking hits and dealing them out as well.

You can also run and jump which is considered "Power" mode
hoursPlayed: but honestly it's just another thing to drain your energy so that you can't zip around and be super armored at the same time.\n\nCombining these two modes with a variety of customizable weapons
voteText: suit up-grades and tactical approaches provides a really interesting and robust way to tackle each encounter. You can literally approach the same scenario differently each time. I found the AI in this game both challenging and interesting at the same time. Enemies actually react to getting shot
helpfulPercent: hide well and as frustrating as a stealth kill that doesn't go unseen (although you think it should be) is - it's good that game doesn't mess around. There will be times when the AI just stands there or runs around sporadically but pound-4-pound it's more of an aberration than an annoying norm. And as someone who is generally kind of over this kind of game in particular that's high praise.\n\nIf you're a fan of the FPS genre then this should definitely be something you play. If you've never played a Crysis game and are burnt out on the FPS shooter genre (like myself) - this is still a great way to pass a Sunday afternoon. The graphics are indeed great
votesHelpful: the gameplay is really tight and overall it's a really fun game."

INTRODUCTION:Crysis 2 is a first-person shooter developed by Crytek using the Cry Engine 3.  It serves as a sequel to the critically acclaimed 2007 game Crysis and is the first game on the franchise to be released on the consoles as opposed to the first game that was PC exclusive.

The game puts the player in the shoes of a U.S. Marine named Alcatraz whose team was sent to Manhattan to assist in rescuing civilians after an epidemic has infected the city.  Shortly after arrival, an unknown enemy attacked their Submarine, thus forcing the team to swim to the surface only to be gunned down by an Alien gunship.  Luckily, Laurence Prophet" Barnes

Cell Paramilitary Forces and the Alien race called the Ceph.

voice acting and music

reviewText:
The following covers only the single player portion of Crysis 2.

For many, the graphical powerhouse Crysis is more notorious for its tendency to bring even cutting edge PCs to their knees, than for its gameplay. While it offered tons of eye candy for those that could run it, the fact remained that most were forced to watch from the sidelines as it was simply impossible to play on anything but the best hardware. But all that changes with Crysis 2, a ruthlessly optimized machine that finally lets all those wondering about the series a chance to see what it’s all about. Unfortunately, it never lives up to its reputation in any way than being a pretty face, and once you look past the visuals quickly evaporates into a game I couldn’t wait to leave.

Everything in Crysis 2 revolves around the Nanosuit, a secret military project which grants the user superhuman powers and provides both tactical and medical support. Armor, invisibility, super strength, and Nanovision (a combination of solar and night vision) round out the list of your abilities, and for the most part you are given free range over how you use them on the battlefield.

This is what sets Crysis apart from other shooters. While still linear in progression, there is a lot more freedom in how you tackle situations than you are typically allowed in a modern FPS. Maybe you’ll choose to go in guns blazing, armor at its max as bullets ricochet off like water drops, or perhaps opt for a stealthier solution and sneak through the water ducks behind enemy lines. Experimentation is encouraged by way of a helpful visor reminiscent of Metroid Prime, which highlights enemies, weapons, and different points to begin your assault. When everything is working right Crysis 2 can be an incredibly rewarding and exhilarating experience where each fight becomes its own puzzle for you to unravel. The real problem though is that these moments are few and far between.

One of the main reasons for this is every feature of the suit is tied into an energy gauge. When you use one, the meter depletes leaving you completely exposed and unable to cloak or use armor. While clearly designed to keep the game from becoming too easy, it also does a fantastic job of taking away from the feeling of being a super soldier developer Crytek tries so hard to create. Getting stuck in a firefight without the suit’s abilities is a common occurrence that almost always results in a near instant death, and even passive abilities such as meleeing enemies and sprinting are tied into the bar, which leaves you essentially helpless once it runs out. Using the energy bar to regulate abilities isn’t a bad idea in theory, but the execution is constantly working against the player to create a frustrating experience constantly stifling its own potential.

The other big issue are the enormous amount of bugs, most of which revolve around the comically bad enemy AI. Cloaking highlights this most, as enemies are entirely oblivious to you when you are cloaked, going so far as to ignore you taking out their comrades mere inches away (I can only assume they are used to seeing their partners suddenly fall to the ground for impromptu naps). Fall into an enemy’s line of sight however and all of a sudden every living being knows where you are. Cloaking then acts as something of an on/off switch for enemy fire which comes grinding to a halt the second you cloke, a useful if entirely unrealistic way to exit a firefight that is equally unsatisfying.

Finally you have the moments when the enemy AI simply breaks, getting stuck on geometry, running in endless circles, and all around being complete fools that are almost more fun to watch than to shoot, because truth be told shooting them just isn’t very fun. When everyone acts like a broken robot it’s hard to feel as if you’ve accomplished anything when you outsmart them, and for as intelligent as Crysis 2’s mechanics may be, every enemy you come up against seems to have drawn the short straw for brains.

The narrative also left me wanting, hitting every cliche in the book and topping things off with some of the most abysmal writing and voice acting I’ve had to endure in a very long time. The interesting premise and opening scene where you, a soldier on his deathbed, are given the nanosuit and along with it the memories of its previous owner, is quickly swept aside in an endless stream of betrayals, convoluted twists, and an inability to ever explain what is really going on. I lost count of the number of times you lose consciousness, only to awake with your allies once again swapped and your motives changed. The writing is overly simplistic and juvenile, turning a lackluster plot into a cringe worthy affair. Rounding out the package is the flat voice acting that never could hit the right emotional tone nor bring any life to the script, but I suppose you can only do so much when given so little.

But if there is one thing everyone is wanting and expecting from Crysis 2 it’s another benchmark graphical showcase, and in that regard it does not disappoint. The level of detail in each scene is astounding, with the lighting effects in particular standing even higher above the rest. Seeing the sun breaking through the dilapidated buildings of New York is awe inspiring, and although I won’t spoil them, the later half of the game is filled with some of the most impressive set pieces I have ever seen. Few games can match the visuals found in Crysis 2 even years after its release, and the amount of optimization wizardry done to ensure it runs well even on lower end machines is nothing short of impressive. Sound design is equally well done, with deafening explosions and gunfire which threaten to blow your subs and does more than anything else to provide a much needed wow-factor to the proceedings. The great score grabbed me right from the opening menu, setting the tone for the game and adding to the overall epic feel of the game.

Undeniably beautiful, Crysis 2 has a lot of good ideas but does a poor job bringing them together. The bevy of bugs and glitches, most notably the terrible enemy AI, took almost all possible enjoyment out of firefights, and the few instances where the game actually worked as intended only further displayed just how much wasted potential was left on the table. What we are left with is a below average shooter wrapped in an extremely pretty package, but one that can’t hide the dull and lifeless game underneath. It’s hard to dislike something that throws so much eye candy at you, but in this case beauty is only skin deep.

Disclaimer: If you are curious why my gametime is so low, it's for the fact I originally played Crysis 2 on the Xbox 360. However my time with the PC version has confirmed that it is very much the same game, aside from the obvious graphical upgrade. If you find anything I said to be inaccurate, let me know and I will look into it and update my review accordingly.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Ever since its initial release in late 2007, Crysis has been touted as one of the most visually impressive games to ever to be released on the PC. But no one really talks about the gameplay too much. That could have something to do with the fact that in order to experience the wonder of said graphics and not just look on in awe as demo reels were shoved down your gullet, you needed the world's fanciest PC gaming rig. Still, there were plenty of people who did have a good enough computer to run Crysis and even more who wanted it to be available on the home consoles as well.

Crysis 2 made that nanosuit-boosted leap through the air to the console market in a brilliant and impressive manner.For part two, the fight has moved from the imaginary island of Lingshan to the very real New York City; the only difference being that in this version of The Big Apple, there's a virus going around that melts people into a pile of goo and an invasion from some very squid-like alien beings. It's now up to you as the man in the fancy nanosuit to give these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s a run for their money. This time around, though, instead of just wandering around an open world and blowing all the pretty bits up, you're guided through a level-based experience that keeps the plot fluid and creates a more streamlined gaming experience.

Somehow the team over at Crytek has found a way to make their sequel just as visually remarkable as the original and without the need to spend a fortune on a fancy new video card and extra RAM.The desolated streets of Manhattan have an eerie presence about them. The once bustling metropolis has a sense of recent and sudden abandon written all over it, like everyone just stopped what they were doing and disappeared. It's the most living" dead city I've ever seen in a game. Anyone that's ever been to the five burroughs of NYC will probably agree with me that the essence of the city has been captured in the graphics.From a visual standpoint
date: the whole vibe of the game is Planet of the Apes meets Escape from New York while the gameplay itself is more Halo meets Metal Gear Solid.\n\nYou can choose to go balls-out guns-a-blazing through every level like a suicidal badass

You could even skip combat all together and just sneak around everything if you're good enough or just bored with fighting. Obviously

But even though you'll figure out that Darth Vader is Luke's father long before you should

reviewText:
Great gameplay and beautiful scenery with a terrible (bad) scenario!That is basically Crysis 2 in one sentence. But let's go a bit further!


The good, the bad and the ugly--, I mean the derp.
The good :It's gameplay.

The gameplay is what makes this game so fun to play. I'm not a huge fps fan of brainless killing and I prefer my fps to be intelligent and have a good and long interesting story. This one compensate the story part by it's very entertaining gameplay and huge variety of weapons (WICH IS GOOD FOR A FPS AM I RIGHT?). I expected this game to be more like a derp shooter where you kill everything, but I actually quite enjoyed the stealth part. But of course, the gunplay is also great.

The stealth part is absolutely not forced nor necessary, but I found it the most interesting part for me. Hearing the soldiers screaming and being all scared is a sadist joy that I don't hide. It just feels really good to sneak around all stealthy with our superior armor and killing them in style.
Speaking of the soldiers, there are 2 main enemies in this game. Human soldiers, and Aliens. The gameplay is quite different when facing them. When you fight soldiers, you feel like... a hunter, a predator hunting his prey. And every kills is really rewarding as you feel powerful. Op even. And feeling powerful is a good feeling (because the game is not that easy on hardest difficulty!).
When facing the aliens, it's quite the opposite. They are numerous, strong and almost scary. This time I often choose to hide. Not because I enjoy stabbing them in the back, but because I'm genuinely scared to face them and their superiority. In this case, I feel like the hunted. Aliens also have some huge boss and they are pretty challenging.


But all this talk about the weapons would not be enough if we don't talk about the ARMOR! Because yes, the armor has such a big role in this game. It's actually it's core mechanism. Other than having the most badass voice you ever heard for an armor, it is also packed with lot of skills and uppgrades. Stealth, superior armor, thermal vision, scanning abilities, superior jump... There are a lot of differents functions. The game is made so that you will need them at least once during the course of the game at some key parts. For instance, I often find thermal vision to be more of a gadget in most games, but here it feels really good to be able to see in heavy smoke or being able to see stealth opponents... But of course, they are usefull for the whole duration of the playthrough. Never made useless.
How do you uppgrade your armor by the way...? Well, here is an interesting way of working. You get more energy by killing aliens! Seems easy right? But aren't they the kind of enemies you would rather avoid? Yes! That's the trick. It's easier to avoid them, but more rewarding to actually kill them!


The graphics :
Crysis 2 has always be known for being a very demanding game when it was out in 2011. And... well, even after 4 years the game is still insanely beautiful. It's not just that it is plainly  looking good"  but
date: the scenery and the actions are absolutely brillants
recommended: unique and gorgeous. You will see some scenes in this game that you never saw before in any other games. New York having a tsunami? Huge tentacle robot coming through the ground and destroying the city? Flying island? Absolutely epic collapsing of buildings and huge explosions? Yes
hoursPlayed:
this game has them all and it looks astonishing.

Miscs :
You can also customize your weapons a little bit. Always nice to have. The game lenght is pretty good if you play a bit more stealth wise and play on hardest difficulty. I would say around 17hours for me since steam misses a few hours.
The bad :It's story.

Oh boy... oh boy. Well

reviewText:
An overall great game with some shortcomings.

I gotta say I really enjoyed Crysis 2. I have not played much of Crysis 1. So, playing C2 was an amazing experience.

What I liked :
1) The graphics & details that make up the environment.
2) Nanosuit modes.
3) Storyline ( although it's short ).
4) Gameplay.
5) Nanosuit upgradation with catalysts.
6) Excellent alien bodies with great warships.

What I disliked :
1) Short story. I finished the story in under 6 hrs of play time.
2) Not many weapons.
3) No boss alien in the end ( It's just a whole lot of casual aliens spawning in the end, no boss ).
4) Cannot use alien weapons ( I think C3 has this feature ).
5) Multiplayer. It's kinda weird to me. Not much of a 'variation' in multiplayer.
6) You can carry only 2 weapons at a time ( excluding heavy weapons like JAW etc ). And so there is nothing like side-arm" in secondary weapons. So
date: two primary guns and you cannot carry any pistol with it.\n\nSo
recommended:
given the things "I" liked the game is really worth it. Pros definitely overcome the cons.
Better give it a try ;)

I'd rate it 8/10."

reviewText: To be honest, I never liked Crysis. I always looked at it as a techdemo. It was one of those games that had numerous glitches - BSODs and audio glitches were frequent and I do not remember any other games with which I was having similar issues at the time. Also, my rig surpassed the system requirements for the game so I never understood what could have caused these issues. But the various websites and forums on the internet confirmed the same.\n\nIn any case, the jungle environment was already familiar following Crytek's Far Cry. So, when the news came that the sequel to Crysis would take place in New York (now an urban jungle")
date: I looked forward to seeing and playing it. The game delivered: the destroyed cityscape of Manhattan looks superb thanks to CryEngine 3. We are to navigate between the floors of destroyed buildings and combat on the city streets is common. Finally
recommended: the aliens appear in the form of regular soldiers
hoursPlayed: too - it's not just the big monsters that you need to fight like in the first part.\n\nAs for gameplay
voteText: the protagonist's nano suit has been streamlined. Strength and speed modes are now combined. We can now perform silent takedowns so following a stealthy playing mode is more rewarding. Upgrading the suit's features is a possibility based on the alien kills we perform - this is an unnecessary role playing section of the game but it does not represent any issues.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: I was satisfied with the sequel. Single player campaign lasts for 12-13 hours which is quite long these days. Cutscenes are frequent and Hans Zimmer's excellent score helps us with the immersion into the world of Crysis. Too bad that starting from June multiplayer mode will be unavailable for good (following the announcement of GameSpy)

reviewText:
This is a Far Cry from the original Crysis.. is that not funny? Too soon? Anyways..

Let me explain first by telling you why Crysis 1 was far more than a tech demo.  It was what marketing teams now popularly refer to as yielding something know as “emergent gameplay” Sure, I'll grant it you it was a technical showpiece when real time shadows on foliage was ground breaking not only for technical achievement but also for your wallet regarding the new GPU you'll need to run it properly.

There was real strategy to be had while playing Crysis. From cloaking yourself, sneaking behind someone and grabbing them by the throat, switching to strength mode and throwing them off a cliff. To tanking and switching in between maximum armor, strength and speed to jump over a fence and blasting unsuspecting fools with an automatic shotgun or on the fly switching between different scopes, applying a silencer, crouching, taking aim (maximum strength, to steady fire) and sniping on the fringe of a base. These are just a small percentage of what the game allowed you to do. All this was combined with a huge open terrain of varying topography.

All of this is exchanged for a easy to grasp corridor shooter in Crysis 2. Now, don't get me wrong I love a good corridor shooter but the freedom of play granted in 1 turns the “freedom” into clearly labeled things within your visor such as get up high and snipe or stealth through the sewers, leaving any guesswork or self discovery out of the picture.

I won't harp on the story of either as I don't think either are truly interesting however nor are they offensive. They are just or sort of latent. Regardless I still prefer the original narratively speaking because I believe the pacing to be a lot better as well as the mystery of what exactly is going on on the island. This is feels more like where else can we take this idea we started with.

After all this reasoning as to why I like Crysis 1 better. Crysis 2 is still worth playing. I haven't played the multiplayer but I don't play much multiplayer anything so that info is better commented on by someone else. What I can say is the gunplay feels great, combined with the exo suits abilities. I'm sure the multiplayer is as fun and competent as the campaign and certainly will extend the life if that sort of thing floats your boat.

reviewText:
Even if I'm giving it thumb down I could recommend this game to certain people. Its a decent shooter, with nice graphics, and some great moments.

However, personally, I didn't like it very much, and theres a lot of reasons for that. Comparing to its predecessor it has improved story, multiplayer, and alien design, but overall, original was a far better game (but still far from my favourite game). Original Crysis was obviously a game designed with PC in mind, and you could see that in every aspect of it - graphics, huge levels, level of destruction, and other stuff. It was ported to consoles years later, but in Crysis 2 version of engine, and with no surprise.

Instead in the jungle on islands Crysis moved to the jungle on concrete, how they call New York, and very popular thing to say during this game's advertisement period. Levels are now far more stiff. Here and there you may stumble upon some more open area, but rarely, soon after you will return to your usual corridor roam. No matter how wide its corridors are, corridor shooter is still a corridor shooter. Initially, it came with only dx9 assets. It got dx11 facelift later, but even after that you can still see a lot of hidious textures, especially on the walls. Here and there you may break some glass, TV screen or a vase, but generally environment is indistructible. You can use carboard boxes as a solid cover or even hide behind cellophane wall. Which is just ridiculous comparing to the original, where you could level down structures, or even cut down the trees with shooting. But this is just a nitpicking, mostly. Despite all of that, even without highres textures, its a pretty looking game, theres no doubt about it.

AI in this game is brain-dead, and I'm not even exaggerating. You may not notice it initially, because of the sheer numbers of opponents you'll be facing most of the time. But sooner or later you have to see how they love that cover... They love it so much that they won't move from it even if you stand right before them, or even after putting a bullet in their body. It happens that they forget about you after you run past them, you or they hide behind the cover, or ignoring the fight which happened just couple of metters behind them. Sometimes they won't acknowledge your presence until you shoot them, even if you are in the open in front of them, in their sight range. Other hilarious stuff includes your marine ally getting killed because he accidentally stopped where scripted event occured and jeep runned over him, killing their colleagues (or even themselves) with their own grenades, blowing themselves up after accidentally shooting the red barrel behind which they were hidding...

But what I hate the most is that camera movement. PC designed original had nice and smooth aiming, unlike Crysis 2. Its not that bad, but no matter how much I'm tweaking mouse sensitivity, I just can't get rid of that feeling like I'm moving controller thumbstick, and not a mouse. Like something drags me down. Lowering settings to get some extra frames doesn't help either (game runs smooth on highest settings anyways). In SP with laughtable AI its tolerable, but in MP its a killer. Yet another sign of its console design. Similar problem I had with Halo 2 PC port, or Bioshock Infinite, yet another console-infested game.

As I said, story is better this time, but again - nothing for an Oscar. You are some US Marine grunt, infiltrating New York via sub with your team. But soon hell breaks loose after alien incursion, your whole team gets killed, and you are saved by Prophet, character from the first game. You will see him just  briefly at the beginning, he is infected by the alien virus, and can't last much longer. He gives you his nano-suit, and puts a bullet in his own head to break the link with the suit. But before that gives you the order to find certain scientist, that guy who your team supposed to find anyways. For some reason, your character doesn't say a single word for the whole durration of the game, not even I'm not Prophet

reviewText:
Crysis 2 improves a lot of the aspect of the original Crysis and Warhead. While Crysis 3 is a big improvements over this game, I still say that Crysis 2 is my favorite out of all Crysis.

The storyline is EPIC!!! Not even Crysis 3 can match up to this game in terms of story. You're a dead man walking killing aliens and fending off the C.E.L.L Ops, but you really get the feeling of Alcatraz pretty quick.

The soundtrack is great. It gives you this feeling that fits the atmopshere/situation so it elaborates the story more.

The graphic is advances for its time, althought it might look like a graphic demo, but this game has its own unique art (unlike Crysis 3).

The gameplay is fine, just what you expect of Crysis, my only complains is we can't prone ~_~.

Overall I suggest to play this game because this is a work of damn fine art!
9.5/10 from me

reviewText:
Overall I would recommend to FPS fans, though it is neither the best nor worst in the genre.

+Good visuals and FPS gameplay
+Some customization choices for suit/weapon upgrades
+Suit skills allow you to play combat or stealth focused roles

-Checkpoint-only save system, no manual/quicksaves (without mod)
-Random freezes/crashes, made more problematic by no manual saves
-Fairly weak and linear story
-Extra DRM for multiplayer, requires crisis account

reviewText:
Reality 2.0. A review from New York.

There is this morbid fascination with seeing New York destroyed in movies. This game does just that and does it really well.

The graphics.

Nothing to say here. Cry Engine 3 is going to dominate the graphics department until Frostbite 2 comes out I guess. It's going to be an interesting stand off. I did however notice some inconsistencies with water. Most water still looks great. However, some parts of the water are just outright consolish looking. As I was playing the game, I found myself constantly being distracted by the graphics whilst I was getting shot at which was annoying. However, when you are invisible, you still cast a shadow and your floating gun is also visible to the enemy. Now the game gives you the option to run around in third-person view.

The story:

Well, you still play as a mute character named 'Alcatraz'. Nomad actually had a voice. And they do attempt to tie in the story with the first game, somewhat. But hey, on the positive note, you can actually cast a shadow and you have legs this time around.

The locations:

There are 19 missions. You start off at Battery park and then you advance towards the downtown area of the city through the East side. You will visit many historic locations and some of them are going to be blown up. The scale of the buildings in the game and reality is almost 1:1. One thing is that the skyscrapers in the background are randomly picked. Apparently the devs did not wish to go through more trouble of placing the real skyscrapers in the corresponding locations. Let's get one thing straight. This is not a sandbox game. At the end of the day, you are given an area that you have to navigate through to get to the next check point. So even though that makes the game linear, the fact that there are several approaches to your destination kind of makes the city your playground. I loved seeing the old closed off Brooklyn Bridge 6 train subway stop. They have only recently re-opened it by the way.
The NYC subway maps that are in the game are wrong though, not to mention some geographical errors. The devs also put the train tracks on the streets, and NYC does not have those except for the old abandoned old track that was delivering coal to a plant a hundred years ago; now it is a museum.
But at least the intersecting streets and historical locations are correct.
The game does give you a significant area to run around when you approach the Grand Central terminal, otherwise the entire game consists of isolated carefully constrained few blocks that you have to go through.
The bottom line is that, it is not really New York as I hoped to see it, but it is New York enough.
Times Square has been pulled off very well, but of course, most of its blocked up by the mysterious US Army cement blocks, seriously? The US army can barricade NYC in the matter of hours of alien attack with thousands of these blocks?
Hint, when you find the head of the Statue of Liberty, go inside of it.

The sound:

The sound is great. Distant shots, shouts, explosions, alien growls, your gun shots - it's all there. Can't comment on the music however, since it ruins the immersion for me, no music necessary.

The gameplay:

Extremely smooth. Quick load times as usual, responsive keyboard and mouse. The recoil is extremely realistic, unlike other FPS games. Even throwing a grenade is bound to give your screen a shake. They slightly augmented the role of the nano suit here. This time, the energy regenerates much faster. Not only that, the energy regenerates no matter what. So even if you are swimming, your energy will eventually recharge even if you do not surface. Needless to say, that makes the game easier than the first one in that department. There is also a cover system even though I didn't use it a lot. It is reminiscent of the Killzone franchise, wherein you remain in cover and you are able to peek out and see what's going on ahead, instead of being able to see everything if you were playing a third person shooter.
You can still grab the aliens by their throat and choose to either knife them, throw them or use them for cover. But you can't just take any alien by its throat. You have to either soften the alien and pump it full of lead first or punch it a few times, then you have the option to grab the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
Sliding. Not really that useful but it's nice to have the ability.
The ability to climb up if you just can't reach that ledge. I found myself jumping from building to building just to grab onto the ledge and pull myself up.
The strong kick. Useful in kicking large things around.
You can upgrade your suit and your weapons based on your progress in the game and how many enemies you killed.
Introducing the nano vision. No more night vision. This time, you can see traces of water vapor or traces of heat or enemies while everything else on the screen remains black and white.
The game gives you the option to bypass your enemies completely, and most of the time you can pull that off.
There is some driving, but it only last a few seconds at a time.

The ammo caches are scattered throughout the city. So even though you cannot carry as much ammo at a time, you will easily find ammo elsewhere.
There are a few types of aliens, but most of them are infantry. You will find some big fat ones and a tripod. You will also see a couple of cloaking aliens.

Also, there really aren't that many enemies to fight in the game. In total, you will perhaps only kill around 150 foes. On one side, it will never get frustrating of getting swarmed by aliens and dying constantly. There is always plenty of room to maneuver. On the other side, it does not really feel like there's a lot of fighting going on. There's a couple of companies of the Army and the Marines roaming the city and there is only a handful of aliens.

The weapons:

The weapons are plenty, probably as many as in Crysis:Warhead. The ones are also introduced. I am only happy to once again comment on the realistic recoil of all weapons.


The negatives:

1. The aliens aren't really that menacing, but they do look like the aliens from Battle:Los Angeles.
2. The invasion does not really feel like a real invasion, but a series of isolated skirmishes.
3. Fighting aliens is a lot like fighting humans, not that I know what it would feel like fighting aliens. But regardless, they do take cover, they do retreat and they don't really have any special abilities.
4. There is a slight re-spawn of enemies but not anything like in Call of Duty series.
5. The game is not an exact replica of New York City. Maybe only 50%-60%.
6. There are some bugs there and there especially with the AI. The AI is good for the most part. But this one time I was laughing my ♥♥♥ off when I saw an enemy soldier jump over obstacles when he actually tripped over the obstacle and fell head down and then got up. I don't know if that was just a crazy physics' engine bug or actually part of the AI algorithm that has a % 0.00001 chance of this happening.



Finally, the production values are off the charts and there really is no good reason why you shouldn't buy this game. And I haven't even played the multiplayer yet.

reviewText:
I bought this game when it came out on the Xbox 360 in 2011 (which lets face it was a historical high point in the history of gaming what with this and Skyrim). I played it through three times. FFwd to 2014, I buy an uber-PC for gaming and get Crysis 1 2 and 3 in a deal. I just finished Crysis 2 for the second time on the PC.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. Conceptually it is a masterpeice. Alien invaders, hostile humans, friendly humans, a terrific and engaging plot with high standards in terms of the script and voice acting. The level design is fantastic with an openess which allows many paths through areas and a game mechanic that permits stealth or force as an approach. The cutscenes do nothing to break the immersion and the scale of events around the player create a feeling of being caught up in something Earth shaking. Literally.

If there was one game that I would hold up as an example to developers of How to Make Computer Games, Crysis 2 would be it. This would be in my top five games of all time. If you have never played it I cannot recommend it enough.

reviewText:
I barely write reviews, but I figure this one was worth it. for $5.99, I finished the single player campaign in one sitting. The 8 hours, it was amazing. About $.75 per hour, but i'll probably never touch it again but the pros are:

1. Gameplay (single player) (8/10)
i. Amazing combat engine, love the suit.
ii. You will use stealth mode for almost the entire game
iii. Ability to turn up the difficulty at anytime, which is fantastic.

2. The storyline (8/10)
i. It was very captivating, played through and read the synopsis.

3. Graphics (9/10)
i. I currently run the game on a 1440 monitor with an r7 graphics card, ran smooth as eggs,
ii. amazing graphics and visuals, no lag, on ultra.

4. Multiplayer (0/10)
i. heard the servers are going down, haven't attempted to play it. so 0 rating.

Final rating 7.5/10 worth $6 bucks, would not spend anymore than that.

reviewText:
So here's my review for Crysis 2 :)

Pros:

+ Nanosuit is something fresh and unique
+ Dynamic and engaging gameplay. Customization option for both nano-suit and weaponry in order to complement player's game style
+ Excellent campaign. I enjoyed mostly of campaign missions.
+ Great storyline
+ Good graphics. CryEngine shows it's power and stunning visuals.
+ Perfect soundtrack
+ Fun multiplayer

Cons:

- Lack of fractions
- Not enough space for player, missions are pretty linear.
- awkward AI
- Technical glitches
- Alomost no destruction, player have not enough interact with game world
- Not well designed small multiplayer maps.

To sum up, Crysis 2 have enjoyable singleplayer, even worth re-playing actualy. Multiplayer is something fun, but not enjoyable enough. Game have lack of open world, differently from it's sequel.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Crysis 2 is an Action FPS with various degrees of stealth and environmental combat. Crysis 2 Maximum Edition was developed by Crytek Studios and Published by EA, Crysis 2 was released in 2011.
Disclaimer: Multiplayer is gone, so that whole aspect of the “Maximum Edition” just went down the drain.
Reference: http://www.pcgamer.com/crysis-and-crysis-2-pc-multiplayer-will-shutdown-with-gamespy/


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You are the Marine “Alcatraz”, Alcatraz inherits the Nanosuit 2.0 from it's previous owner whom calls himself “Prophet”, and now everyone in the game will call you prophet for half of the game.
(This greatly annoyed me... to the degree that after an NPC exclaimed, “It's Prophet! Kill him!” I would promptly turn around and pummel him to death with my rifle stock.)

The story itself is a little bit tough to follow if you've not played the first game (like I haven't), but having a large repertoire of sci-fi media background I easily caught on to what was being discussed within the game. The story is about as interesting as you can expect from a FPS from 2011 (in my personal opinion that's nothing to be proud of).

I've also felt that architectural cues are being lost on me, you play through the destroyed streets of New York City. I have been to NYC once, but I felt like a lot of the geometry in the game was referencing the city, but was ultimately lost on me since I'm not very familiar with NYC.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=521987017

Gameplay: The gameplay was the most enjoyable feature to Crysis 2; the Nanosuit 2.0 has a variety of upgrades which can be purchased after you kill and collect samples from the extraterrestrial aliens.
There are several ability enhancing traits the Nanosuit 2.0 offers: Sprint, Jump, Armor, Stealth, and Nano-vison. All of these abilities require suit energy, so there is a limited amount of time you can use these abilities, using multiple abilities drains energy even faster.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=521987110

Achievements: There are no Steam achievements for Crysis 2. There were achievements for the Xbox version of the game, so someday there might be an update with achievements, but at this time there are none.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=521987145

Price: Crysis 2 – Maximum Edition is priced at $29.99. Unfortunately “Maximum Edition” is a fancy way of saying “here, download extra junk you can't use, because there isn't multiplayer anymore”.
Buy the game when it's on sale, the game itself should be priced lower for the content and the amount of time it will take to play through the game. One play through will take approximately 6-9 hours, depending on the difficulty and how “completionist” you are.

Conclusion: All in all, Crysis 2 was a good game. Mediocre sci-fi story. Entertaining and rather flexible gameplay. No steam achievements at this time. Over priced, wait for a steam sale or bundle deal.
I recommend this game to people who enjoy FPS, but unfortunately this fall into my “play and forget” game categories, so ultimately it doesn't have any niche that sets it apart from other generic story-driven FPS's out there.

------Edits and updates------

reviewText:
Crysis 2 is a first-person post-apocalyptic shooter developed by Crytek Studios and published by Electronic Arts. The game was released in March 2011. The story continues from Crysis 1 where the Ceph invaded the Lingshan Islands into them invading New York, USA. The player plays as Alcatraz, a member of Force Recon One, whose mission to infiltrate and capture Dr. Nathan Gould goes terribly wrong. This review will discuss the campaign and the dialogue, the gameplay and the features, performance and graphics, and the issues with the game. I did not test the multiplayer component as the online portion went offline in 2015. In addition, the Maximum Edition aspect of the game is irrelevant as all of the contents were related to multiplayer.

Crysis 2 encompassed a good and logical storytelling campaign. The story expands on the Ceph invasion into America from the Lingshan Islands and the inevitable counter-attack by the Americans. Furthermore, the game provides great insight into the background of characters that carried before and through both games, notably Prophet and Jacob Hargreave. For instance, Prophet reveals that following Crysis 1, he found out it was not the last of the Ceph, rather the beginning of a new war. The story in the game made sense by the end of the campaign so I commend Crytek for elegantly telling the story. However, I do not like the massive logic gap from Crysis 1 to 2 because the sequel does not mention the aftermath of the cliff-hanger in Crysis 1 as the aftermath is explained through the Crysis comics series, which irritated me and I feel is an unwise business move. But, the dialogue in the campaign was excellent in telling the story. I completed the campaign in 10 hours and my favourite component was the team-based missions alongside the US Marines because many post-apocalyptic games result in a lonely protagonist. My second issue within the campaign was the lack of real excitement in cut scenes that clarified a major part of the overall story. For instance, when Jacob Hargreave reveals his knowledge about the Ceph, which I will not spoil, it comes across as another cut scene, not as a great storytelling moment, even if it was. Lastly, this game features some collecting aspects such as collecting dog tags on missions, collecting flashbacks, and so forth. It's not overly filler but it's not overly interesting to invest the extra time into finding the extras. Overall, the campaign is good because the story within the game, not the overall story is told with depth and precision and has minimal loopholes. The main issue of having to follow the comic series to determine what happened in the cliff-hanger from Crysis 1 does hurt my overall experience of the campaign.

Crysis 2 possesses a variety of gameplay features to mostly improve the game. First, the game features a levelling system in which Alcatraz can kill the Ceph and garner Nano Catalyst points to upgrade his nanosuit. There are four different tiers with three upgrades in each, which is separated into tactical, armour, power, and stealth module tiers. This is a decent system because it allows you to improve Alcatraz's overall combat effectiveness and it has a nice balance to not overpower him but improve him because as the campaign progresses so does the difficulty of the Ceph. My major annoyance with this system was the lack of clarification if an ability is active or not once you purchase it. For instance, if I buy threat tracker, the game does not mention whether its active. The second gameplay feature is the layout of missions in the campaign. I really like the layout of the missions because despite the game being linear, you can approach a mission in a variety of ways. For instance, when Alcatraz opens his visor, he can see his tactical options for the mission, which may be going 100 metres to the right through stealth to complete the mission or going forward 30 metres and grenade the enemy. Furthermore, the weapon customisation system expands on the variety of approaches in a mission because Alcatraz can alter his gun depending on what approach he wants to take, ie. Stealth approach and a silencer. This freshens the gameplay and missions because Alcatraz has various options in completing a mission and can suit his equipment towards that approach. Lastly, the weapon combat, melee system, and vehicle movement and combat are all smooth, fluid and enjoyable. Vehicular combat does spice up the game, particularly on long distance missions. Overall, I commend the gameplay and the variety of features because it all does enhance the game experience.

Crysis 2 has very consistent performance and beautiful graphics. This game reinforces why Crytek were the leaders in gorgeous games because this 2011 game is truly a stunning game. The graphics are superb, from the destruction that affects the landscape to the realism of characters to the overall tone of the post-apocalyptic atmosphere. Furthermore, I like the simplicity of the UI, which is the main menu. The performance as mentioned, is very consistent. On my mid-tier system, which specs are highlighted on my profile page, I played on very high settings and drew a constant 35-50 fps. When there were FPS drops throughout a mission, there was no stuttering, making performance steady throughout a mission. However, at the beginning of the majority of missions there would be a major freeze probably due to a massive fps drop for some unknown reason. Loading times varied in the game. Some missions took longer to load than others, which was annoying on some levels but not a major nuisance. Overall, the only hitch in performance was the start of the mission stuttering, but for the most part this was a smooth game. Likewise, the graphics was top-notch.

Despite most of the review containing positives and some containing negatives, this game had a ton of bugs and glitches. I encountered six bugs and/or glitches that occurred frequently throughout the campaign. For instance, the worst was the sound engine dying, resulting in me restarting my computer. The second worst annoying bug was dialogue showing up on the screen as I had subtitles enabled and the characters that were meant to say those lines went silent, pointing to more issues likely with the sound engine. And the other bugs and glitches was mainly relating to dialogue, event sequences and gameplay. All in all, the issues did hurt the game for me.

Overall, Crysis 2 is a good game that features a logical and competent campaign, great gameplay and features, a beautiful atmosphere and environment and consistent performance for the most part. This game had a deep and logical story that explained the specifics and the broader picture. It provided fluid combat and various approaches to tackling missions, freshening the linear aspect of the game. The main issues was the logic gap from Crysis 1 to Crysis 2 due to the business idea that the story should be advanced through Crysis Comic series and the amount of bugs and glitches infested into it. This game is $29.99 and you can get up to 18 hours in my opinion on the game fitting in the campaign and the extras. At $29.99, I recommend getting this on sale. However, if you are completely new to the series, I recommend getting the Crysis Collection at full price of $44.99 because there is three different games that tell a massive story and all of which have been well received.

Ratings:
I calculate the point system by rating each component I discuss and then averaging the total and deducting marks depending on the amount and severity of issues within the game.

Campaign: 8/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics and Performance: 9.5/10
Overall: 7.75/10

Thanks for reading my review! If you liked this review, rate it and join my review group. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page.

Not usually a huge fan of FPS games, I can say I really enjoyed playing Crysis 2, the visuals are superb, the story is prety decent but doesn't get in the way, the controls are easy to work with and the normal difficulty is forgiving enough to a fairly poor player such as myself.

- length of game is fine, and there is plenty of side stuff you can busy yourself with.
- plemty of checkpoints, so dying isn't too much of a pain

The not so good (but dont be too put off)
- I'd have liked a larger range of weapons.

I didn't attempt to play the multiplayer, and the game supports 21:9 monitors natively.

reviewText:
2-sentence review for the solo game : if you play 2 FPS games per year (or more), Crysis 2 will bring nothing new nor memorable to the table. It is however still a decent entertainment with a few perks, despite a lot of downsides.

Pro:
- alien invasion gets some nice magnitude near the end of the game
- the combat suit & its powers are relatively nice to play with
- a few enemies are really hard and it gives a few intense fights, especially when they pair near the end of the game !
- solo campaign is not too short, something like 10-15 hours if you don't speed-run all the way

Cons:
- rhythm is very scattered because we have to pause to regain health & power every 30 seconds
- stealth is OP & too easy
- spam-hitting enemies with our rifle butt is OP
- often alien enemies could easily kill us from a distance, but they always feel the urge to rush to us without firing to get spam-hit in the face with our rifle butt (and it's OP ;-) )
- where is the final boss ? The final battle ? Hello ? Anything ? Anyone there ?
- globally too easy, with only a few hard passes
- no munition management : there are just munition boxes everywhere ; there are at least 2 or 3 times more munitions than an average player needs to kill all the enemies
- you have to rush to get essence out of the killed aliens before it disappears ; in normal combat, it's already painful, but if you want to be a snipper, it means you'll never get the essence, and thus you won't be able to get the enhancements based on them
- story isn't even worth a B-Movie (oh, 1 of the guy giving us orders by radio will actually betray us, what a surprise ! ;-) )
- you can't shoot ill zombied" people

reviewText:
The game starts out decent enough where you can stealth and approach obstacles with different strategies, much like the first Crysis. With that said the stealth system is broken, where you can destealth behind a cement divider and a guy 100 meters away will just start shooting at you.

However the game eventually turns into a horribly paced non-stop action filled shooter (that's not a compliment) where the only thing you can do is just shoot enemies and run to the next check point. Now this wouldn't be so bad but the gun play is awkward and the suit powers are pointless besides using stealth and armor if you are dumb enough to stand in direct fire.

There is so much happening every second that you just stop caring about a building falling down or another alien ship crashing or defending your comrades from attack for the effing 100th time.

The story is paced poorly as well and incredibly predictable. A large poriton of the campaign feels like pure filler. About 3/4 through the game the entire plot is frozen and you spend what seems like an enternity assisting the remaining marines in evacuating a dozen civilians and performing frustrating missions.

I do not recommend as a Crysis fan I did not want a COD experience. I got maybe 5-6 hours out of this game before it turned into a shooter on rails. The first part of the game wasn't exactly 10/10 either.

reviewText:
Many fear Crysis 2 to be the franchise’s turn from an open-ended objective-based shooter into a linear shooter that parrots the gameplay trends of all the other AAA shooters these days. For the most part it is, but that doesn’t stop it from being better than almost all those games. It’s very different from the original Crysis and Crysis Warhead, but Crysis 2’s level design still has a certain quality that’s rare these days.

If you can find my user reviews of Crysis and Warhead, I described those games as possibly the last examples of sandbox-style mission design where you’re free to tackle objectives how you want in absolutely massive maps. Crysis 2 chucks that whole approach for something more similar to Call of Duty or better yet Halo. Crysis 2 has obvious chest-high walls for cover everywhere, quick-time events, a storyline about aliens and mercenaries that’s generic despite having been written by a published sci-fi author, upgrades bought with experience points, and generally gives players fewer options than its predecessors. It doesn’t however shove you down straight corridors, but maintains some semblance of the franchise’s open-ended nature.

Where in the original Crysis players would get a full map of an area and multiple objectives at a time, Crysis 2 will display a single waypoint at a time at the other end of a medium-sized area with maybe three or four routes through it. You might see a sky bridge flanking around some enemies, a hole in a barricade, or a small tunnel underneath the area. And the game will directly tell you all this by highlighting weapons and routes on your tactical visor, assuming you’re used to more linear shooters.

For what they’re worth Crysis 2’s levels are pretty well-designed. It’s still possible to sneak through most areas of the game and play the whole thing stealthily. When firefights do break out, instead of just popping in and out of cover you have a lot of room with which to employ some positional strategy on enemies. Effectively it’s like fighting in a Halo game’s combat arenas but with fewer vehicles.

The nanosuit’s powers have been adjusted a bit from the earlier games but the same general strategies apply: use cloak to sneak by or flank enemies (prone is gone by the way), throw objects and leap around with strength, etc. The main change is that armor mode is no longer the default but must now be switched on manually, so you have to factor it in when managing the suit’s energy. Speed mode is pretty much just the sprint which automatically consumes suit energy. Strength is actually just a super jump and a melee attack.

The aliens in Crysis 2 are simultaneously a bit more interesting to fight and more boring in how they work. In the earlier game Crytek tried to make them feel more “alien” by having them float around in the air with vague shield abilities, which could often make combat with them feel odd. In Crysis 2 they behave a lot more like humans as they walk on land, use what look like guns, and generally behave like your human enemies. Because they have different weak points and can sometimes disable your suit energy though, you still have to approach them differently. There’s one interesting new boss-type enemy that appears a few times throughout the game, and Crysis 2’s final combat sequence manages to be an unusually interesting and challenging fight.

One area in which Crysis 2 is unquestionably an improvement over the original is its visuals and its strain on your hardware. The sequel both looks and runs better than the first game, especially in DirectX 11. I guess being released on consoles meant Crytek had to actually optimize the game this time. Crysis 2’s use of lighting, post-processing, bokeh depth of field, and tessellation put it above all but a handful of games released since 2011 in terms of tech. It’s probably one of the earliest games to reach the threshold we’re seeing on PS4 and Xbox One now.

On my i5 and GTX 760, on maximum DX11 settings in 1080p the game runs at 60 frames per second almost all the time, occasionally dipping down to 50, and never going below 40. However, like its predecessors Crysis 2 does suffer the problem of locking to 24Hz when played in fullscreen on a TV. Forcing a borderless windowed mode with external software can fix this.

To compare, in my earlier reviews I called Crysis and Warhead simulations of 80’s action movie tropes where you can manipulate the mechanics of Predator and First Blood Part II however you want. Instead of a simulation, Crysis 2 feels like a game -- everything about its levels and mechanics has been transformed into a smaller set of rules Crytek wants you to follow, but within those rules it’s still one of the better games on the market.

reviewText:
God dammit. God, ♥♥♥♥ing, dammit. You had it, you guys were so close. A great story, great mechanics, an open-world freestyle approach. It was all there, in the palm of your money-grabbing hands. But you ♥♥♥♥ING threw it out the window. What does this game offer me now? WHAT?!? Characters I could give less ♥♥♥♥♥ about? A few Alien mob types and the same scenario for every engagement because of the linear path? How about those enhanced graphics, huh? Oh wait, what about all those explosions and cut scenes!?
Yea no, I'll just go watch a Michael Bay movie.
For two years of waiting (TWO YEARS, let that sink in) you get the ability to upgrade your armor to an almost mind-numbingly un-customizable degree. And it doesn't even matter what play style you were going for because you might as well be elevated to level of God by the end of the game; you'll have every damn perk that has existed and ever will exist. Walk into the middle of a fight and just sit there as the enemy mobs ♥♥♥♥ their pants at the sheer might of this ♥♥♥♥ing suit that can take your crap and turn it into gold. Where is the skill you need? Where is the approach? It's gone.
New York City! Awesome I can't wait to run around street to street saving the day bashing Alien heads in! Naive. So naive.
I can't continue this review anymore, it's just too depressing.
So pick up a copy today, I guess, if you like killing Aliens or play Call of Battlefield 16: Let's Kill Middle Eastern People and need a change of scenery.

reviewText: No...sometimes I try to go back to this shooter that now can be played in a wonderful steady 60fps ultrawide 1080p....but no, the game is just extremely boring past the first two levels. In a way it feels like crysis: the suit works, the weapons are customizable and all and gunfights are challenging. There is a very sad lack of scenery though. The whole map and scenery is completely soul-less, plain, boring, without any art at all. If in the first crysis it was wonderful to go around the enemies, surprise them, explore the forest and take a sea route, here you are confined to some urban streets, very few open small buildings (where you can even notice the copy-paste of the props), even the horizon looks closer than it should and everything feels confined, while in the original Crysis it was amazing to feel the first island (and the other levels) and the possibilities that it offered. Of course it was no Oblivion or Skyrim but it was still something much more interesting than this call-of-duty-styled sequel. It just doesn't fit it well :(

reviewText: Crysis 2 continues in the steps from the first game but this time taking place in New York. Much is the same from the first one, but the graphics engine has been much improved and the suit abilities have been simplified making the switch from different powers very easy, as well as upgrades have been adding allowing the player to use upgrades tailored to their playstyle. Graphics wise my frame rates always held at 60 FPS and the visuals are stunning as ever. The campaign is pretty lengthy (took me over 8 hours to complete) and there are various weapons at your disposal; as well as each level has scattered collectibles to find which unlock extra e-mails or artwork from the main menu. The levels are all visually stunning and the gameplay is rock solid. If you're a fan of the first Crysis game or looking for a top notch FPS game Crysis 2 excels.

reviewText:
A visual treat of a follow-up to Crysis, the sequel completely changes direction and almost suffers from it, if not for its otherwise excellent game-play.

Whilst Crysis and Warhead did very little truly interesting in the narrative department (with Warhead at least trying to do something about addressing that) the sequel quickly puts you into an entirely new environment and situation with very little explanation into a world that is a mess. Being ferried from one set-piece to the next on a strictly linear and far narrower path, I quickly realised that I was losing focus on what was going on with a conflict that seemed to spring out of nowhere and whilst there are obviously connections to the original, they seem tenuous at best. Crysis 2's narrative is a mess and whilst Crysis got away with its minimalist approach as it didn't shove it right up your face, it's hard to ignore the silliness going on in 2 as it, unfortunately, does shove it in your face.

The plus of all of this is that the core game is still very fun, if not severely reduced in scope and potential variation. Replacing open objectives are checkpoints along a trail that mostly replaces the how you approach an encounter with where you approach it from; the game does at least provide different routes for you to approach fights from that can give eager travellers an upper hand. This is particularly important given that the nature of your enemies have changed and whilst you're still fighting a lot of humans, you also have various alien enemies to take out, from foot soldier equivalents to large walking annoying bosses.

The removal of island openness does at least make way for some truly fun set-pieces though as the further you get into the game, the more interesting they become culminating in an extremely fun final level. As memorable as some of them may be though, there is an inherent reduction in the replayability in the game; you can only approach encounters in so many ways, set-pieces are only unique the first time and weapon variation (both in what's available and how many you can carry) limit the empowering craziness of the original and Warhead.

Ultimately, 2 feels very much like an extension of the ideas in Warhead, but at double the length and losing what made Warhead a fun in-between point of Crysis' openness and general FPS linearity. By the end of this game though, whilst I had felt satisfied, I was in no rush to play it again, nor even consider how I would attempt to go back to that particular set-piece and try completing it in a different manner. Essentially, there's one good run here before the game feels like it has expired.

Whilst Crysis 2 does look fantastic and has a great sound-track to boot, it lacks much of the uniqueness that its predecessors had whilst only providing minor boosts to the things that already made it a great shooter. Fun overall, but a greatly reduced experience overall.

Multiplayer: There's a greater push for the MP component in 2, but it essentially plays out like many small map-based shooters. A few interesting quirks here and there, particularly in your suit-enabled movement, but otherwise an extended feeling from the main game, that of competency and not much else.

The shots missed me luckily.

reviewText:
Well, where to start? This game is a great example of corperate greed. Yeah, that sounds about right.

First off, the storyline is mediocre. I wish I could understand it, I really do, but to me this is like an epilogue to a poorly written spin-off of crysis. That isn't even the beginning.

Gameplay...Basically, it's Call of Duty with a nanosuit. Gun play and other mechanics mostly found in multiplayer are extremely close to CoD style, Crysis was it's own game and didn't rely too much on other games for ideas. That has come to a close with Crysis 2. Oh, and I almost forgot that everything is much more linear in the campaign than the original one was aswell.

Multiplayer, yet again it's CoD with a nanosuit. In Crysis 1 you had tanks, vtols, and helicopters, and you had a CS styled buy menu, everything was bought with points you earned. Now, it's default weapons with class loadouts and unlocking new weapons requires leveling up, sound familiar? Oh, not to mention killstreaks such as Radars and Radar jammers, air strikes, and a ton of other things. Oh, and Mesa, the biggest MP map in the original crysis, is probably bigger than all of the MP maps in this game combined.

But if it's so bad

reviewText:
Very nice game and a must-buy during sales. The single player campaign offers hours of game time and a very good story. The graphics are amazing and so is the sound. Crysis 2 provided a good mix of stealth, full-on action, vehicular combat and differing environments. As I played Crysis 1, Crysis Warhead and Crysis 2 one after eachother, I found Crysis 1 to have the better gameplay due to the more open environment. Crysis 2 offers the best storyline and fun. The 'tactical options' do add some choice, but seems only a thin layer above the heavily scripted game progress.
I also tried multiplayer for a dozen matches. Should always be some servers around to have some fun. The multiplayer uses a reward system to progress your capabilities which means you will take alot of beating when starting. Nothing too frustrating though, as I found the mp matches fun and fast paced.
Overall, a highly recommended FPS!

Score: 8/10

Pro:
+ excellent graphics
+ immersive story
+ nanosuit capabilities
+ decent multi-player

Contra:
- console-ish control system sometimes suffers
- 'tactical options' only suggests open game world

reviewText:
Possibly the most advanced, complete, and entertaining corridor shooter ever made. Years after release, it remains the king of the genre.

If you like halo, call of duty, and so on, this game should be a must play for you. If you're more into the deus ex/crysis/crysis 3 experience, you'll probably still appreciate all the things crysis 2 does exceptionally well. If you're a die-hard crysis OG fan, your blood is boiling reading this positive review by someone with Prophet as his steam avatar.

Which is fair. Everybody's allowed to have their opinion. But I implore that you recognize crysis 2's mastery of corridor shooting, to the point where it's hard to notice that you're in a corridor.

As of late 2014, multiplayer no longer works, but the singleplayer is excellent, and the soundtrack is excellent. If you see it go for 15 or less, it's a worthwhile purchase, but more than that is probably a bit too much for a digital download of a game with discontinued multiplayer.

reviewText: I remain ambivalent towards first-person shooters in general, and Crysis really does nothing to change that.  However, the graphics on offer are just so much better than anything else on offer that it's a noteworthy game.  Even now, several years after release, this is probably THE game to use when you want to see just what a new rig or GPU will do.  With loads of brightly colored outdoor environments, the game fortunately eschews the repetitive, bland and drab palettes of competitors like Metro.  The crispness of the textures, depth of shading, and wide range of color gamut still have the power to bewitch sixty times a second.

reviewText:
It is rarely that I have played an FPS that managed to impress me and keep me on the edge of my seat with its action and at the same time completely impress me with its storyline. Mind you Crysis storyline might seem generic and cliche as they come and there's a definitely an element of truth to that.

Having played this game in 2016, almost 5 years after its release, I can certainly say that if you told me this was a 2016 game I've would have believed you. Sure the player models might seem a little stiff and dated, especially in a gaming era where facial animations are scrutinized constantly and Crysis 2 is worthy of complaints in that matter, the textures and the environment however still look as beautiful as ever. The times of old memes (WILL IT RUN CRYSIS) are perhaps gone, but this game is certainly worthy. Still looks good, especially in the maximum edition where it features the High Res textures.

Crysis 2 gameplay is also pretty damn good. There's smooth movement, decent aiming, the action flows greatly and constantly at your own pace; you can take a stealth route to eliminating your enemies or you can go guns blazing. Naturally in higher difficulites a proper combination of both strategies will net you a quite satisfying and intense experience. The gunplay is great, there's a variety of different weapons to use, each one with their own stats and modifications. Don't worry, it's super simple to customize your weapon and you can do it on the spot too! No need to go back to a bench/whatever to modify your gun.

You want to stealth this part of the mission? Add a silencer and a scope. You want to fire more bullets? Add extended clip. You want a secondary function to your primary weapon? Add a grenade launcher! It is important to note that not all weapons have the same modifications and some unique and powerful weapons might not have any at all, but still this is a great feature which has unfortunately been completely ignored in the modern FPS.

Last but not least, your nanosuit is essentially what makes you an unstoppable soldier. There's armor mode to reduce damage taken and stealth mode which makes you invisible and allows for a more stealthy approach. The modes are mutually exclusive which makes sense and use energy. Furthermore you can upgrade your suit as well with different enhancements which can also be done on the spot as well! Improve your armor absorb, make you stealthier, decrease the energy drain etc. Admittedly there around 15 to choose from but they are there and they can define the way you play through missions.

For completionists, there are several collectibles scattered around the different levels which include: emails to expand on the lore, collectible dog tags, collectible car keys and souvenirs from New York.

The level design is magnificent. The city of New York looks wonderful,   even after the Ceph invasion and destruction, the map progress allows for a semi-linear if you will completion of objectives. Don't think that this is not a linear game. It totally is, however there's a degree of freedom in which you can complete some of these objectives. You can avoid enemies if you will, flank them, use vehicles, detach turrets from barricades etc. The gameplay is absolutely great, never a dull moment and it keeps you on your toes constantly.

Now for me of course, since I'm a sucker for 90s/early2000s blockbusters (The Rock, Independence Day, Armaggedon, Crimson Tide, Black Hawk Down) the story is pop-corn entertaining fun. The dialogue is as good as it gets, you get your epic speeches, your betrayals, your arrogant villains, basically all the tropes you'd expect in a movie. And you know what? It ♥♥♥♥ing works. It works so well in the concept of the game and it fits perfectly. And I cannot stress enough that all of this would otherwise seem silly if it wasn't for the exquisite soundtrack by no other that the master himself, Hans Zimmer. Hanz Zimmer is one of my favourite music composers and he's also the primary reason why I fell in love with the Single Player campaign of Modern Warfare 2. The soundtrack is epic and it intertwines with the gameplay, superb dialogue and the game itself in such a way that I think that any other soundtrack would have seriously affected the way I felt after I finished Crysis 2.

Now the negatives which definitely exist but by no means take away the joy of the game. The enemy is AI is a little bit weird, don't expect smart enemies who will try to do everything in their power to kill you. Even at max difficulty, they behave is a rudimentary way. They hide behind cover, they fire, sometimes they might throw a grenade or two and they will try and move towards you. Nothing fancy and a bit on the silly side at occasions especially whenever stealth is involved. The models look a bit dated as I mentioned above and lip-syncing might be non-existant at moments. Notable example is the soldier talking to you while wearing a surgical mask, really shows that the developers didn't want to bother with lip-syncing and facial animations with the exception of some key characters. Most of the dialogue is transmitted to you via voiceover in the suitcomms however said dialogue I believe is vey well written  for the context that the game is based on.
I'm not saying that this is the best dialogue in the history of gaming, but for the cheesy action packed game Crysis 2 is, the voice acting and the dialogue is brilliant.

Lastly the game is a bit short, not as short as such of the 4-6 hours of modern FPS single player campaigns (I estimate around 8-10 hours if you also want to get all collectibles), there's very few Quick Time Events but there are there, cutscenes while great tend to border on the unnessecary at times but overall Crysis 2 is a one of the greater games of genre and you should have the pleasure of playing it. I got this at less than 5 euros during a sale and I think it was a steal compared with the entertainment I got out of it.

tl;dr: Crysis 2 is a brilliant FPS and you should definitely have the pleasure of enjoying it yourself, strongly recommended, a true classic.

reviewText:
As you play through the Crysis 2, you could not throw out the idea that something is missing with the game.

Nearly the first half of the game is dull and boring. These parts are like the game is throwing you some unrelated maps, where you either choose a stealth aproach or go for a direct assault. Hence you feel like you are playing some challenge maps rather than playing a campaign. Combining with the poor AI, technical issues like crashes to desktop many times and falling out of map, you are highly disappointed.

Luckily, with the mission that you met a crew of soldiers, the game starts to rise, both in atmosphere, gameplay and story. From this moment on, it is kind of that you step into a complete different game, and that game has its moments. It is a shame that the developers force you to play a good portion of the game in a dull manner, after you see the second part.

As a conclusion, I recommend the game. Besides it's great visuals and sound effects, Crysis 2 has the essence. It is sad that this essence is not fully used, if so, we would have another Half Life 2 at hand.

7/10
