reviewText:
A visual treat of a follow-up to Crysis, the sequel completely changes direction and almost suffers from it, if not for its otherwise excellent game-play.

Whilst Crysis and Warhead did very little truly interesting in the narrative department (with Warhead at least trying to do something about addressing that) the sequel quickly puts you into an entirely new environment and situation with very little explanation into a world that is a mess. Being ferried from one set-piece to the next on a strictly linear and far narrower path, I quickly realised that I was losing focus on what was going on with a conflict that seemed to spring out of nowhere and whilst there are obviously connections to the original, they seem tenuous at best. Crysis 2's narrative is a mess and whilst Crysis got away with its minimalist approach as it didn't shove it right up your face, it's hard to ignore the silliness going on in 2 as it, unfortunately, does shove it in your face.

The plus of all of this is that the core game is still very fun, if not severely reduced in scope and potential variation. Replacing open objectives are checkpoints along a trail that mostly replaces the how you approach an encounter with where you approach it from; the game does at least provide different routes for you to approach fights from that can give eager travellers an upper hand. This is particularly important given that the nature of your enemies have changed and whilst you're still fighting a lot of humans, you also have various alien enemies to take out, from foot soldier equivalents to large walking annoying bosses.

The removal of island openness does at least make way for some truly fun set-pieces though as the further you get into the game, the more interesting they become culminating in an extremely fun final level. As memorable as some of them may be though, there is an inherent reduction in the replayability in the game; you can only approach encounters in so many ways, set-pieces are only unique the first time and weapon variation (both in what's available and how many you can carry) limit the empowering craziness of the original and Warhead.

Ultimately, 2 feels very much like an extension of the ideas in Warhead, but at double the length and losing what made Warhead a fun in-between point of Crysis' openness and general FPS linearity. By the end of this game though, whilst I had felt satisfied, I was in no rush to play it again, nor even consider how I would attempt to go back to that particular set-piece and try completing it in a different manner. Essentially, there's one good run here before the game feels like it has expired.

Whilst Crysis 2 does look fantastic and has a great sound-track to boot, it lacks much of the uniqueness that its predecessors had whilst only providing minor boosts to the things that already made it a great shooter. Fun overall, but a greatly reduced experience overall.

Multiplayer: There's a greater push for the MP component in 2, but it essentially plays out like many small map-based shooters. A few interesting quirks here and there, particularly in your suit-enabled movement, but otherwise an extended feeling from the main game, that of competency and not much else.

reviewText: This is only a barely above average shooter with some above average graphics. Sure the graphic are great, if you only compare it to a console game. Games like The Hunter and Battlefield 3 that were designed with the PC in mind, blow this game out of the water in the graphics department. Truly a shame, as that was one of Crysis' most redeeming features.\n\nYou can see the influence in other areas as well. Smaller maps, less players in multi player, cut prone feature. A lot of options ended up getting cut or just tossed due to balancing around the console versions. It isn't that this is a really terrible game, it’s just if you were expecting a sequel that took FPS to a level like the original did, you will be disappoint.

reviewText:
Loved the intro!!  Guys at every corner! My only issue was running out of ammo.. haha..  I got the game on sale (maximum edition) and I love the graphics.  It's also cool, I must admit, to be able to kick a car over with my mega powers!

I started the game and was stuck in it for 3 hours! I think it's a keeper.

Since I'm only 3 hours in (at my slow pace of lurking and such), I can't give a full review I suppose but I can tell you that up to this point it is awesome! I had trouble breaking my way away from it.

The abilities to increase armor and to go into stealth are awesome. You can melee in stealth if no one's around (silent kill) and I have to practice at throwing my grenades to where I get more damage per throw.  Lots for me to learn but yeah, it's awesome, I think!

I took tons of screenshots if you want to check them out & I'd like to also recommend earbuds or headphones. I prefer ear buds.. It's easy to forget your surroundings if the lights are also down!

Enjoy! And for the price I paid, I can honestly say I did not waste my money!!

For those looking into Crysis 2,play Crysis 1,this one is for those that care for the story of Crysis and even if you do,theres not much to gain here.

In short you are given a powerful suit that has a power limit but can be made into a bioweapon that can kill aliens(because smashing them and shooting them isn`t as effective).Also the last owner shoots himself because reasons.

So your to do list:

1.Kill Cell troops(typical soldiers)because they want you,well not you,the suit.
2.Find a guy in a city that is being attacked by squidwards with guns and by a disease made by said squidwards.
3.You kill squidward like aliens with guns because ♥♥♥♥`em.
4.You help US soldiers protect their stuff.
5.You stop helping them because you need to kill some peeps(Cell troops)
6.Very interesting story part with aliens.




Don't play this if you are not a fan of generic fps shooting with invis or more health powers, linear story or linear fighting/stealth sections(you choose if you want to do it loud or silent but nothing changes in the story or other sections).Play Crysis 1.

reviewText:
While it lacks the open world of its prequel, this is a pretty fun game. Levels, althrough of the corridor-shooter variety, are varied and do allow for some variations in tactical approach. Typically, the shooting occurs in arena like settings with either waves of enemies to take out as they arrive, or with a large number present, but still in need of taking out. But how you choose to do so is up to you. Stealth kills work due to the suit's invisibility and weapon silencers (weapon custimization is a breeze), sniping is also an option, but the real fun is just going Rambo; sneaking up on an enemy, killing it, grabing its partner, throwing it into and explosive barrel, leaping over the flames, landing with a stunning stomp and unloading a clip, or two, or three. Sprinting for cover, cloaking and flanking, putting shields up and wading into the fray with a shotgun vomitting shells.

The downside is that it can get a little repatative. Yeah, ok, I killed the last few guys with the sniper, the gusy before that with running and gunning, the guys before that with a stealth kill.....after a while the fights do just become a slog. My remedy to that has been to simply play the game in 1-hour bursts to keep it a bit fresh.

I would recommend picking up this game to anyone who enjoys Crysis or FPS games, although I would suggest waiting for a sale.

reviewText: Crysis 2...What should I say? So much drama...So many intrigues... All that due to EA's independence lust. Anyways, to TEH REVIEW! I think that Crysis 2 is a great followup to Crysis 1, which was quite...revolutionary in such type of Shooter games. One thing you'll notice first is: Almost all the abilities are gone from the ability ring. Now we have only our known Visor, Shield and Stealth there. The new ones would be the modifications for the body and the weapons -- I'll get to that in a second. I think that they did it greatly by integrating trivial things as super-jump and sprint into the good ol' buttons of SHIFT, and SPACEBAR. Now, I think that the ability to modify your weapons and body from that ring is GREAT, and I am mostly interested about body modifying. The ways to modify your nanosuit are great, sometimes even overpowered. reviewText:
One word to describe it: Beautiful. It is absolutely beautiful. Even on mid end laptops like mine, it looks incredible. The color and lighting makes this game look so realistic, and the intro video to the game is the most epic intro I have ever seen in a game. The graphic quality is on par with the best games TODAY (Despite being almost 2 years old), and easily wins over most FPS. The score is by Hans Zimmer (who also composed the Dark Knight), and is very well done. The gameplay is special - it kind of reminds me of a combo of Battlefield, Blacklight: Retribution, and Halo. Elements from each game polishes this one, and the campaign is a lot of fun. Got it from the Humble Bundle, and very happy that I donated and got this game:)

Overall:

Graphics: 10 out of 10. This game challenges big ones like Planetside 2 and Battlefield 3 in terms of graphics. CryEngine 3 for the win!

Gameplay: 9.5 out of 10. In this game, you are more than just a character... you are a WEAPON. Stealth and strength are your main tools; you can either choose to use stealth elements and make the combat feel like an FPS Metal Gear Solid game, or use Maximum" elements and go bananas on the enemies using brute force.

Campaign: 9.5 out of 10. Has good replay value
date: and long story line.\n\nMultiplayer: 8.5 out of 10. The multiplayer is awesome
recommended: but you may need to be very patient. My first few matches online were miserable... I was confused on how to set up my classes
hoursPlayed: and the people online are very competitive. There are lobbies dedicated for "Recruits"
voteText: but those are always filled up
helpfulPercent: so good luck on "Standard" or  "Pro" lobbies. Doesn't take long to adapt
votesHelpful:
however.

Overall score: 9.5 out of 10. All I could say is... I regret not buying this game any sooner. I will buy the entire series (Crysis Maximum Edition and then Crysis 3) very soon. A MUST play.

"

reviewText:
Crysis was a commando game, essentially. You were alone, no hand holding you, just go in, do your ♥♥♥♥. You're the Rambo-Predator hybrid.  The dude in the suit was a faceless numbnuts, you were playing as the suit, and the gameplay was about playing as the suit.

Crysis 2 you're special forces. You're fighting constantly, it's a close struggle, but you're vulnerable and somehow taking on waves of enemies. Your suit is a utility rather than a necessity, and that plus the lack of HUGE nonlinear levels in the sequel are the key differences between the two.

Crysis 2 can be positively looked at only in its shooting mechanics, which feel very nice and are responsive, with guns that have unique behaviors and customization.
But hey, Crysis 1 and warhead had that as well.

Summary:

In Crysis 1, I could approach objectives anyway I wanted to.

I could stealth into the enemy camp, grab men by the throat and toss them through a wall to create a breach. I could cut down pieces of palm trees, attach C4 to them, and toss them a hundred yards downrange with maximum strength. The only limit was my own creativity.

Compared to that, Crysis 2 was an utter waste of time.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The practice of witchcraft has obviously continued unhindered at Crytek HQ, because Crysis 2 manages to look even better than it's predecessor. However, unlike it's predecessor, Crysis 2 doesn't quite manage to get quite as much right, and not even ridiculously beautiful visuals can patch that up.

Unlike the first Crysis, Crysis 2 sets it's scene in a post-invasion New York City that has been partially infested by the alien Ceph. Players take the role of US Marine, Alcatraz, the only believed survivor of his team. Upon arriving in the city, you soon discover that an alien invasion is upon the planet, and meeting 'Prophet' you quickly set off to put a halt to the invasion equipped with all the wondrous capabilities of the Nanosuit.

Sporting an updated engine, Crysis 2 is a simply beautiful game. While some may disagree, it's quite plain that Crysis 2 is in fact better to look at than the first game, with improved lighting effects, tessellation and rendered models. Light slithers through leaves casting majestic rays to the ground, bricks jut from the walls and shatter on impact while dust kicks up at the vibrations of your firearm. Crytek's second iteration is a spectacular action ride with a phenomenal soundtrack composed by Hans Zimmer himself, and vertigo inducing cityscapes that would put a movie to shame. I don't usually get quite so worked up over something quite so trivial as visuals in a game, but in this instance, you just can't take an achievement such as this lightly. On a different note, the game play has been streamlined from the first game, with the Nanosuit ability interface from Crysis replaced with one that combines strength and speed into a single mode, and binocular and identification vision implemented into the suit, instead of as external tools. Furthermore, a climb and parkour system helps to speed the flow, overall creating a far more slimmed down experience that actually does improve the game in some respects. While some may disagree, I do feel that this far better fits Crysis as whole.

Thanks to the improved engine, Crysis 2 was able to run on last generation's consoles, but because of this the game doesn't quite look as good as it could have been, and does suffer from some limitations that could possibly have been avoided had the game been designed as a PC exclusive like the first game. Environments, while aesthetically pleasing and atmospherically different, are far more linear than in the previous game, which does cause the game to become boring after a while, as we are constantly spoon-fed the next section with little room to breathe. While the sound effects are still of top notch tier, the actual selection of weapons available is in fact far smaller than in the first game, meaning that you feel like less of an overly-equipped bad ♥♥♥, something I'm sure we can agree isn't exactly a selling factor. In addition, while the story does well to justify your marine/ alien kill spree, it simply isn't quite as gripping as the first game, with explosions and falling buildings seeming to happen *just-cus*, eventually numbing you to the action.

The multiplayer is still present, moving from an open Battle-Field-like approach and to one that more resembles Call of Duty. Again, the excellent graphics do wonders to patch up some of the game's more minor flaws, but unlike the previous game, they don't do enough to hide some of the more jarring facts. It would appear that Crytek substituted innovation for convenience in the production of the game play mechanics themselves, and because of that we have received a game that feels like it could have been so much more had the team not been hindered by limitations of the console scene...

+ Yet again phenomenal graphical fidelity
+ Streamlined game engine
- Linear world
- Numbing plot that doesn't quite match Crysis'

7.5/10 ~ Good

EpicSouls (Sam)

reviewText:
Crysis was a commando game, essentially. You were alone, no hand holding you, just go in, do your ♥♥♥♥. You're the Rambo-Predator hybrid.  The dude in the suit was a faceless numbnuts, you were playing as the suit, and the gameplay was about playing as the suit.

Crysis 2 you're special forces. You're fighting constantly, it's a close struggle, but you're vulnerable and somehow taking on waves of enemies. Your suit is a utility rather than a necessity, and that plus the lack of HUGE nonlinear levels in the sequel are the key differences between the two.

Crysis 2 can be positively looked at only in its shooting mechanics, which feel very nice and are responsive, with guns that have unique behaviors and customization.
But hey, Crysis 1 and warhead had that as well.

Summary:

In Crysis 1, I could approach objectives anyway I wanted to.

I could stealth into the enemy camp, grab men by the throat and toss them through a wall to create a breach. I could cut down pieces of palm trees, attach C4 to them, and toss them a hundred yards downrange with maximum strength. The only limit was my own creativity.

Compared to that, Crysis 2 was an utter waste of time.

reviewText: Crysis 2...What should I say? So much drama...So many intrigues... All that due to EA's independence lust. Anyways, to TEH REVIEW! I think that Crysis 2 is a great followup to Crysis 1, which was quite...revolutionary in such type of Shooter games. One thing you'll notice first is: Almost all the abilities are gone from the ability ring. Now we have only our known Visor, Shield and Stealth there. The new ones would be the modifications for the body and the weapons -- I'll get to that in a second. I think that they did it greatly by integrating trivial things as super-jump and sprint into the good ol' buttons of SHIFT, and SPACEBAR. Now, I think that the ability to modify your weapons and body from that ring is GREAT, and I am mostly interested about body modifying. The ways to modify your nanosuit are great, sometimes even overpowered. reviewText:
While it lacks the open world of its prequel, this is a pretty fun game. Levels, althrough of the corridor-shooter variety, are varied and do allow for some variations in tactical approach. Typically, the shooting occurs in arena like settings with either waves of enemies to take out as they arrive, or with a large number present, but still in need of taking out. But how you choose to do so is up to you. Stealth kills work due to the suit's invisibility and weapon silencers (weapon custimization is a breeze), sniping is also an option, but the real fun is just going Rambo; sneaking up on an enemy, killing it, grabing its partner, throwing it into and explosive barrel, leaping over the flames, landing with a stunning stomp and unloading a clip, or two, or three. Sprinting for cover, cloaking and flanking, putting shields up and wading into the fray with a shotgun vomitting shells.

The downside is that it can get a little repatative. Yeah, ok, I killed the last few guys with the sniper, the gusy before that with running and gunning, the guys before that with a stealth kill.....after a while the fights do just become a slog. My remedy to that has been to simply play the game in 1-hour bursts to keep it a bit fresh.

I would recommend picking up this game to anyone who enjoys Crysis or FPS games, although I would suggest waiting for a sale.

reviewText:
Crysis 2 is epic. It is easy to get lost amongst the sheer scale of the seph-torn cityscapes of Manhattan, a city breathing with life due to the technically impressive CryEngine 2. That's right, the graphics are spectacular, with a great attention to detail, and cater to a range of builds. Other than the jaw-dropping, mouth-watering visuals, the combat in this game is excellently paced, challenging and genuinely fun. There is a large variety to weapons and suit upgrades, accommodating for a great many number of playstyles. The soundtrack does very well to harmonise with the constant action, in particular the main theme, composed with grandeur by Hans Zimmer. The story is fairly straightforward, with a foreseeable arc, although it does have its fair share of surprises.

Tl;dr Crysis 2 (Maximum Edition) is an excellent first-person action game, with beautiful visuals, varied gameplay and a really enjoyable campaign.

9/10

reviewText: The story kinda just drops you into the thick of things, skipping over an exposition. Honestly, it's generic though so you can piece it together yourself after a few minutes. Actually, I suppose that means they did the job effectively. Later in the game the plot, continuing from Crysis 1, actually thickens but I just never became invested in it or the person I was playing as. Although the first game was admittedly linear, this game felt even more so. Actually, I have the perfect way to convey what I mean. The single player campaign for Crysis 2 was basically a Call of Duty style campaign. If that doesn't help then I'll speak plainly: The whole game is just a sequence of set-pieces separated by auto-checkpoints. e.g. You pop up on a bridge and have to sneak past a patrol and through a gate. You can activate Tactical Vision and it will point out all the methods/routes you may take to get to the next checkpoint. Then you try one. If you die you can reload and try again. And again.\n\nGameplay is identical to the first but some of the controls have become more intuitive. No more Strength mode, you only get super strength when you throw something or jump over a tall obstacle. (To steady your sniper scope you can now hold your breath.) No more Speed mode either, you get speed when you sprint. Cloaking and Armor mode remain. I found this new system much, much more efficient than the original. Nobody walked around in either of those modes anyway.

reviewText:
Cautions: A bit buggy with some graphics cards (however their are usually some workarounds such as underclocking your gpu, etc.).  Multiplayer master servers have been taken down so nobody plays online anymore.  Not a lot to it, you can beat it in less than 15 hours if you're good at fps, or don't feel the need to slaughter everything that walks across your path.

Pluses:
This game is pretty.  It's Cryengine's showcase game so that's to be expected.  Still pretty by today's standards.
This game has a lot of variety.  You have objectives, and obstacles that get in the way off those objectives.  Fortunately there's a lot of ways around those obstacles.  You can snipe them, cloak and then come up behind them and knife them, charge head on with an assault rifle, throw grenades, ignore them completely and run past them, find a tank and run them over, etc.  So that's fun.  Note: It is really hard to kill the armored brute aliens by punching them to death, I advice Jaw rockets from a safe distance.

Modding available and encouraged by devs.

The AI is fairly clever and is fun to play against, though sometimes it feels like they're cheating when they aim at you when you're cloaked.  The story is...well really cliche'd, but mostly engaging.  You nearly die a lot, it kind of gets a bit old.  I got this game as a gift, so I'm not sure if I would pay full price for it or not - but if it's on sale go for it!

Having never played Crysis before, I had no idea what was going on with the story or why there are aliens in downtown New York, but that's not really important I suppose.  I'm a nano-suit wearing badass, I'm there to shoot them in the head not ask questions.  Also I couldn't flirt with the cute girl which was disappointing (couldn't shoot her either, also disappointing), but at least she doesn't die.  That would be very disappointing.

I kind of like the soundtrack.  Also Lockheart hates me.  :(  What did I ever do to him!?

reviewText: A great game that plays like your typical shooter, that repetitive run and gun kind of game that is just fun to sit down and play for awhile. The difference in Crysis is that it has the options to let you choose your playstyle, analyze the area with your visor then choose to either sprint and jump around the batlefield shooting from position to position, or activate maximum armor and go head on with an lmg, or even activate nanovision and cloak mode and go Sam Fisher on your enemies. Built using the CryEngine the atmosphere and enviroment is astonishing and adds the cybernetic/futuristic flair to the game with your actively updating hud and in-game menu systems". Put on the suit and prepare for war. 8/10"

reviewText:
How should I start...

The good part about this game is that you get to have more fun with the Nanosuit. New engine means new improvements to the gameplay and graphics over its predecessor. More weapons means more fun! And yes, you can now use the turrets available for you.

The Nanosuit's functionality has been improved. You have power and speed at the same button, so you don't need to switch so much. Armor is active this time around, instead of the default when your Nanosuit loses energy in Crysis.

The bad part of this game? The storyline. Too cliché, and too predictable. It's like something that came out from a Michael Bay movie.

If you're in for a good and action-packed FPS game, then this is the one for you. Just, don't care about the storyline too much.

reviewText:
TL:DR – First person shooter with limited RPG elements. The gameplay is more linear than the 2 previous Crysis games and you may actually find it a lot easier because of the new nanosuit upgrades. Excellent game 9/10.

If you’ve played Crysis and/or Crysis 2, you’ll know that millions of years ago, an alien race placed a huge amount of war machines deep underground with tunnels leading all over the world. After an elite team of nanosuited soldiers explored the alien presence on an remote island, the only character to return is Prophet, the team leader who kind of went crazy at the end. Now you find out that Prophet wasn’t actually crazy, but had a secret mission to gather as much info as possible about the aliens now known as the Ceph. Unfortunately for Prophet, his extreme exposure to the Ceph has contaminated him with the Spore, a kind of bio weapon that the Ceph have unleashed on New York to wipe out all the humans.  You take on the role of Alcatraz, a Force Recon marine sent into the quarantined New York City to help Prophet, and you end up taking on Prophet’s nanosuit when he falls.

Unlike the first couple Crysis games, the nanosuit isn’t just a tool; it’s a major plot point. The suit’s super advanced computer software is working on a way to combat the spore and save the world, not just kick alien ♥♥♥. Your main nanosuit powers have been streamlined since the previous games and now have 2 main “modes” (armor and stealth). Instead of having Speed and Strength modes, those powers are now integrated into your actions. For example, you can pick up a large object and toss it without switching to strength, or you can use stealth (cloak) and speed at the same time. By the way, the stealth mode is probably overpowered in the single player campaign. You can turn invisible and sneak past about 90% of the enemies in the game if you want (no reason not to sneak past the human enemies unless you like gunning people down).

However, when it comes to alien enemies, the best solution is peace through overwhelming firepower. There are more than a dozen different weapons to choose from, and you can carry 2 of them at once (5 if you count the “disposable” weapons). Like in the previous Crysis games, you can customize nearly all of the main weapons with attachments such as silencers, scopes, and extended magazines. If you want to do things quietly though, just sneak up behind the enemy and do an instant stealth kill with your melee. It’s not only silent, it’s also a good way to pick up the nano catalyst that aliens leave when they die. The nano catalyst is like money that you can use at any time to buy upgrades for the suit. There aren’t many upgrades to choose from, but they can be quite a boost (and they carry over to your next playthroughs, so future campaigns are a lot easier).

Pros:
+Excellent graphics, and the game is actually less demanding than the previous Crysis games in terms of hardware requirements. The game is taking place in the city, so there’s no waving grass and tree foliage to stress your graphics card.
+The story is decent though I know a bunch of people didn’t like it. You get a nice variety of enemies and a large variety of ways to dispose of them. Crysis 2 isn’t open world, so the story and gameplay is pretty linear. You don’t need to drive all over an island like in Crysis 1.

Cons:
-Like I mentioned earlier, the stealth mode is probably too good. You can stay invisible for about 20 seconds and just run past all the enemies. This is especially true after you’ve beaten the game at least once because you won’t need to fight aliens for nano catalyst (you’ll already have bought all the upgrades).
-It’s a hefty installation size (about 14 gb) for a game that I beat in about 7 hours.

Overall, the game is great fun and you can replay it a few times before you really get bored of it. Online multiplayer requires an additional sign up (it’s not through Steam).

reviewText:
Crysis 2 exceeds in graphics, gameplay, optimization, audio design, music, etc. Even the story is pretty good, written by Richard K. Morgan, who wrote one of my favorites, Altered Carbon.

Set five years after the first game where you first witness the Ceph in all their terror on Langshan, the Ceph have made their way to NYC, an urban jungle (as described by Crytek devs). I think the most remarkable thing about Crysis 2 might be the attention to detail with the recognizable buildings and showing their true height, just looking up at them in a video game shows how massive NYC can really feel from a virtual perspective. Obviously, it helps that the CryEngine is perhaps the best engine out there in terms of graphical prowess.

I really liked the story, mainly because I'm a sucker for sci-fi games. So the various twists and military factions you encounter while trying to survive from the Ceph was nice. Granted, it's rather easy to survive from the Ceph is you use cover appropriately and kind of strategize your plan of attack. Or you can stealth your way around them, I did that a few times just to see what would happen; can't do that the whole game though as really, most of the Ceph you'll have to kill just to move forward.

I didn't check out the multiplayer, but I bet it's pretty cool. And the way the game ended definitely set it up for Crysis 3, gonna play that soon.

9.3/10

reviewText:
Crysis 2 starts the same as Crysis 1 finished; muddled, confused and frustrating. It very often leaves you fighting for your life, without any clear idea as to what you are actually supposed to be doing. This is a fault that plagues the game at a number of different points.
The game doesn't give that sense of freedom that was in 1, feeling much more constrained and scripted; much most like a console game, which of course it is.
One thing I really dislike is the inability to save whenever you like. All you get is checkpoint saves. This means that a particularly tough section you may have to play and listen to all the commentary again and again and again...!
Having said all that, it's still a very enjoyable game. It gathers pace as you play it, so stick at it for a while. It's a definite must have" even though I still prefer Crysis 1."

reviewText: Captain Tang, played exquisitely by Ricky Gervais, leads a team of Exterminators in this biopic about the man who wiped out the Beaver-tailed Cockroach. Gervais lends a certain je ne sais quoi to the role of the Chinese Pest control expert based, as you know, in Stuttgart. With secondary cast members such as Flava Flav (Mister Tyquavius) , Carrot Top (Eugene Blaczowicz) , Nick Cage (Nicholas Enclosure) and Mickey Rourke (Gina McManaman) you can tell the developers really put thought into the casting. They are met with issues though as the local powers that be, Congresswoman Patricia Lockheed (Catherine O'Hara) and high flying attourney, Patrick Deiter (Matthew McConau♥♥♥♥) look to prevent them from wiping out the local bugs as they have a shady vested interest in keeping them alive. The choreography for the Roach Fighting gambling ring was absolutely on point. This special edition comes with an interview with Tom Hardy, who had absolutely nothing to do with the production. Fantastic.

reviewText:
Crysis games we're known for being Benchmarking powerhouse, but its beyond that. The original Crysis game is a first person shooter with tactical elements, unlike many blatant games of the similar genre the game offers you a variety of options.

Crysis 2 is a sequel with tactical improvments and nanosuit changes, unfortunately they removed the sleep darts and you don't get a silencer from the start of the game. The scenery is less impressive than the previous game but it still eye appealing, and still crysis 2 has amazing cinematic effects. The weakest point about the game is the writting, but all crysis games suffer from it, the most effort was put into Graphical fidelity and Game mechanics so personally I don't mind about the plot.

A lot of Critics say that Crysis 2 is a mundane First Person Shooter, I disagree and I say eat a bag of bricks. Crysis 2 despite for not having a fascinating plot and some content removed it's still a underrated gem with futureproof game engine. I higly recommend on playing the hardest difficulty for more enjoyment. Because of you getting instantly killed with few shots your only option will be to engage in tactics.

Also the performance is surpizingly amazing, I'm an overclocker myself and on my low-end gear it runs fantastic.
I get 55-61 FPS on Max Settings, vsync off.

GTX 650 Ti 1GB GDDR5 (OC @ 1085Mhz Core 3.300Mhz Memory)
Intel core 2 Quad 2.4GHz (OC @ 3.6Ghz)
Muskin Silverline 8GB.


This is rarely a very good EA Game, you don't get that often.

A lot of Critics say that Crysis 2 is a mundane First Person Shooter, I disagree and I say eat a bag of bricks. Crysis 2 despite for not having a fascinating plot and some content removed it's still a underrated gem with futureproof game engine. I higly recommend on playing the hardest difficulty for more enjoyment. Because of you getting instantly killed with few shots your only option will be to engage in tactics.

Also the performance is surpizingly amazing, I'm an overclocker myself and on my low-end gear it runs fantastic.
I get 55-61 FPS on Max Settings, vsync off.

reviewText:
This game isn't worth 30$, but if it's on sale I would recommend it. I think it's worth a good 15$. I give it a 7/10, the campaign is the strongpoint of this game. Let me explain,

The campaign is outstanding. It's definately a step up from the last game, the opening of the story was just perfect. There are a few flaws in the campaign, such as once you're in a vehicle you're almost invincible. You are also very overpowered, and unless there are a lot of soldier or aliens fighting you, you're most likely going to go trhough the fight unscathed. The graphics are very good. One problem I have with this game, is there are only a few choices for weapons, and the starter weapons are some of the best. The maps are pretty small, and the invisible walls will get on your nerves. I give the campaign a 8.3/10
The multiplayer isn't that great. The weapons are very unbalanced, and it taked about 2 hits with the auto shotgun from medium distance to kill you. Also once you've played about 2 round, stealth (invisibility) is useless because you can still see them. The community is pretty bad, most are hardcore gamers who play this game all of the time, and the maps are very small. Sniper are always an instakill and sniping is also very hard. I give the multiplayer a 5.7/10
If it wasn't for the campaign, this game would have been a disapointment.

reviewText:
CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is a first-person shooter video game developed by Crytek, published by Electronic Arts and released in 2011 as CRYSIS 2 REGULAR EDITION before being later released as CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION in 2012. It is the sequel to CRYSIS aka CRYSIS 1.

Set during the Great Depression of 2023, CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION focuses on Prophet, a nanosuit-wearing mute soldier from a poor family of tenant farmers driven from their Oklahoma home by drought, economic hardship, agricultural industry changes, and bank foreclosures forcing tenant farmers out of work. Due to his nearly hopeless situation, and in part because he was trapped in the alien invasion apocalypse, Prophet sets out for New York. Along with thousands of other generic gun-fodder soldiers, he sought jobs, land, dignity, big guns that can murder ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, and a future.

CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is infrequently played in American high school and college literature classes due to its lack of historical context and nonexistent legacy, plus the fact it is a video game, not a book. A sequel, CRYSIS 3 MAXIMUMEST EDITION was released in 2013 to general lack of interest, but it's only on Origin, and who would want to use Origin? Nobody, that's who.

Anyway, CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is not very good.

reviewText:
It's fundamentally fun to be The Predator, and that's what's important.

Streamlining the suit to (mostly) Q/E for tanking/flanking means you can be a nightmarish ambush predator who suddenly appears from unexpected angles carrying a heavy machine gun and shrugs off return fire, before vanishing again to relocate. Or picks off a squad one-by-one, unseen, as the shrinking pool of survivors panic.

It's not so hot when it's trying to be Call of Duty, sheparding you from cutscene to cutscene with a bunch of squaddies you care nothing about hovering around. Forget the plot. It's utter dreck, and perhaps telling that by the latter part of the game I'd actually forgotten which of the two names the protagonist gets called was his real one.

But most of the time, you are in a survey/ambush/evade/reposition loop, and that is fun times. And this appears to be the only Crysis title without third-party DRM in singleplayer (multiplayer still needs an online account and is probably long dead anyway). Get it in a sale, learn to filter out the word nano"
date: and stab some invaders in their fleshy squidparts."

reviewText: The only thing I heard about this game before playing it is how good it's graphics are, but the gameplay is good too, for example: many games lets you choose between being stealthy or go gun blazing through the levels, but usually you will be choosing based on the benefit you get (go stealthy to save bullets, kill all enemies to get EXP maybe) but in Crysis 2 you get to choose as you like due to the fact that you can only equip one upgrade of each of the 4 slots, and the cheapest upgrade in each different slot is quite good and enough to carry you through the whole campaign so you won't worry about killing all enemies to get all the NanoSuit Points (similar to EXP).\nThis and some other things made me like the game althoughI am not a FPS games fan

reviewText:
Consolization
Crytek decides to address the consoles for its next chapter of Crysis, enriching its history but with the consequences of being designed to run on limited hardware.

PROS:

- Excellent artistic direction (although it was designed thinking on consoles, Crysis 2 boasts a spectacular design of the city of New York, enemies and characters).
- Wonderful attention to detail (from the photos on posters of missing people in the disaster to the inside of a newsstand, Crytek's hand into this title is pretty evident).
- Solid and immersive history (a new step forward in the narrative structure of the series, answering questions from the previous installments and paving the way towards the close of the trilogy).
- Weapons arsenal quite varied and original.
- Long Campaign (beyond collectibles scattered in the most remote corners of the maps and the relentless search for accessories for your equipment that may already increase your playtime).
- Improved IA over previous titles (although there is the possibility that enemies can stuck" in specific places of the maps).

CONS:

- Consolized (From the ridiculous FOV of the render of the weapon you hold
date: passing through the reduced level design and ending with the simplification of controls and gameplay elements).\n- Multiplayer support is discontinued (with the shutdown of GameSpy servers there is no active multiplayer... but
recommended: there are ways...)\n\nA solid game all around
hoursPlayed: especially in the artistic and narrative department. However
voteText: fans of the two previous installments probably be disappointed when they see how much the saga has been reduced
helpfulPercent:
technologically speaking.

My Score: 8/10
Note: Played it on Microsoft Windows 7 Ultimate - 64 bits"

reviewText:
A major thing to note is that as of june 2014 multiplayer servers are offline due to the Gamespy shutdown. So don't buy this expecting a multiplayer, and knowing EA they probably won't do anything to resolve it any time soon.

At the Full price of $30 usd at the moment I don't feel it's worth it. If you find it at half price or less I'd say it's worth picking up.

Single Player:
The story is well developed and sticks to the storyline of the crysis and warhead and evolves it quite well, which is apreciated these days. The customizable nanosuit was a nice addition in making the game fit your playing style a bit better. On another note the story is very linear, basically there's not really much replay value. It's also a pretty short campaign which sadly I've come to expect anymore.

Graphically:
Crysis 2 does feel a little watered down compared to it's predecessor, probably due to trying to break into the console market at the time. Don't get me wrong it is a gorgeous game texture and lighting effect wise, it just feels like all of the small deails built into crysis and crysis warhead were lost with this release.

reviewText:
I quite enjoyed my time with You Gotta Get Outta Here Simulator 2011, known in PAL territories as We're Outta Time Buy Me More Time 2.

Here's the thing about this game,
I didn't like it much when I first played it, on all but the highest setting, yeah you can do things how you like, but that means you hardly have to think at all, just gunning everyone down is a reasonable option as long as you stand in a corner.

My second playthrough, however, I bumped up the difficulty to the highest, and that's when it became apparent to me how refined the gameplay really is.  You're forced to learn little tricks and make certain tradeoffs, you're made to choose precisely from which angle you want to initiate an attack.  It's really very well done, and much more refined than the original Crysis, which I believe to be overhyped on account of its eye candy.

There are certainly cons though, so I'll list everything out here in bullets:

PROS
----------
Beautiful graphics (if a little “smoky” at times)
Adjustable FOV (thank god for that cause it's awful)
Really smart, approachable, tactical gameplay (love)
Optimised suit controls over the first game
Really optimised performance-wise over the first game
Smarter weapon customisation system
Suit upgrade system adds much-needed depth
NewGame+  (more or less)

CONS
---------
*Really* generic, boring, military characters
*Really* generic, boring, military dialogue
*Really* generic, boring, military soundtrack
*Really* generic, boring, military cutscenes
Lots of weapons but still only two at a time (hate)
16 suit upgrades but only 4 at a time (haaate)
No useful unlocks of any kind from any difficulty completion

CONCLUSION
-----------------
If you're into standard military shooters, you'll find something extra here, and doubtless have a good time.
If not, you'll have to take time to understand the game's mechanics fully before you can really appreciate it, and have to sit through a *lot* of dumb, tough-guy talk, but it's still very possible to have a great time if you focus on the fantastic stealth gameplay.

Crysis 1 - 8/10
Crysis 2 - 8/10
Crysis 3 - 7/10

reviewText:
This is my review of Crysis 2.

The singleplayer. Unforgetable experience. The champain was amazing. It blew my mind. I liked the armor upgrades and the customizable weapons in it too. The fact that i found no glitches was amazing as well. All was running smooth even on my laptop wich isnt that good. If youre looking for a game with a mind blowing singleplayer this is the game for you! I rate the singleplayer a pure 10/10!

The multiplayer wasn't the best. It has a minor setback than the first crysis (i didnt play it but saw some videos of it) first of all maps. Alot smaller. Second the multiplayer got way too fast paced. I like fast pace. And a big fan of slow pace. But this was a little too fast for me now this is personal opinion some might love it like this. But the fact is that multiplayer runs 20 frames per second while singleplayer runs 60. Now i do like the xp system and the dog tags and all. And the pure multiplayer mechanics so i give the multiplayer a 7.5/10

My conclusion is that this game is definetly worth it for the singleplayer and if you like fast pace the multiplayer as well. This game must be the best game i played in the past couple of months. So go ahead and buy it!

The only reason people don't like this game is because they believe they do not need a focus on good graphics to have a good game. So the graphics in this are so astronomically great that the game itself suffers from a poor lack of focus on gameplay even though that is not the case. If you like any of the Metro games you will enjoy this game for its stealth or loud options and good story; there is also a PvP multiplayer mode which associates this game with cod which a lot of people like to not like too.

Put this game up on the Source Engine and you automatically have a game of the year for the same gameplay with lesser graphics.

reviewText:
Despite recommending this game, my feedback is qualified: I cannot really put in words the disappointment I felt when, with the game's settings universally set to Ultra, the first reveal of the game (when you emerge from the warhouse that Prohphet shot himself in the head in) showed that I was playing a sequel that looked quite some distance worse than the groundbreaking original.

I say this not because I'm a shallow graphics-♥♥♥♥♥, though of course I am to a certain extent, but because the immersion breaking consequences of a massive dropoff in technical achievement thoroughly robbed this experience of anything approaching the uber-ambitious gameplay - and the CURCIAL sense of wonder - of the original. Frankly, the buildings of NYC in this game look like they've been transplanted from a rushed-out-the-door licensed Spiderman game from the mid-00s, and how am I supposed to feel like a badass when the - let's admit it - utterly cheesball design of my character is the best looking part of a game that was spawned from a ground breakingly, heart achingly beautiful game?

It goes beyond the graphical achievements of the game, though. I understand that all of this downscaling was done as a result of the move to consoles, and I understand that by now I'm looking at a game that was scaled for the xbox 360 - there's no way it'll look anything like Metro 2033 Redux, for example - but I just cannot deny that the game is just less fun than the original was. In this game you basically move down linear coridoors - albiet city-street-sized coridoors - with the megerest of alternate routes threaded around them, whereas in the original (If you haven't guessed it now then I am indeed saying that Crysis should be bought immediately without delay if you haven't played it yet, certainly in preference to this game) one had what truly felt like a wide open island environment to cloak, drive, or blast your way around.

Okay, so the game is uglier and more constricted than the game it was supposed to be a sequel to. So why have I recommended that you get it? Because it's a good shooter on it's own, and when sales time comes around it is going to be worth picking up. Put it on your wishlist and bide your time, you will get a good looking, tight shooter with tactical combat and a lot of fun additional gameplay tweaks, with a bit more character building (not story development, character building) than the original thrown in. Get it. If it's on sale.

If you haven't played Crysis, do so immediately.

reviewText:
I remember years 2010 and 2011, when I finally changed my hardware from P4 to something with more cores... I've played ALOT of FPS shooters then, collecting all I previously was not able to run properly. And it comes that way, that I've played the first Crysis game just before I've started the second volume.

The difference was staggering. Mind-blowing. And disastrous.

I've tried to give it the second chance lately, but alas, all that was new and good in 2011, now looks so plain and common, no juice left in that volume. Get me right: I've finished it, all the way through, on the highest difficulty. I just don't like the way I was treated all time through.

Let's speak of good things: for one, Crysis 2 has a better temper for hardware. The first Crysis caused me several BSOD during the last boss fight, but there everything was running smooth. Well, not exactly smooth, really. I'd rather use the word Kosher"

reviewText:
Well another story untold...

That's the way it is game after game.  Game developers assume everyone plays for the blood and gore and not for anything else.

I play for the story and the idea, that stuff they make all the cut scenes for, and I know I am not alone, but people know you can't get a game company to do anything but what's cheapest for them to do.  Stories require more work, more expense and are seen to be less profitable -- a short term view.  But, alas, I digress, for why should any gaming company be different than any other, right?  They should all be the same, have the same policy toward players, swap out PR people from one company to another, all use the same group of elitist beta and alpha testers, and, usually end up with them running the very forums they direct us to for support (Kinda explains why so many games are so identical in so many ways, and boring right?).  Yeah, game after game putting down corporate interests" and "greed" done by company after company.... or more accurately "corporation after corporation
date:
whose entire interest IS greed.  Game companies are one of, if not generally, the highest profit margin available, 20% or more due to most of what they're selling being automated integrations, and those figures have only gone up since the company doesn't have to even produce a box, disc, or pay for shipping to some box store and is now a downloaded, entirely electronic product.

So, yeah, recruit mode in Crysis 2 is too difficult for me.  I want to see the game world, to enjoy, and not be frustrated by, getting there.  I find little enjoyment in not being able to save the game when I want to save it, instead of relying on checkpoints that assure when I die to have to go through again what I was already sweating to go through the first time with 3 meleeing aliens on me at once, only to die to another one later due to their extended melee range compared to mine (to keep that blood and gore challenge assumption thing going).

So I dedicate this review to all the silent gamers who spend money on games they uninstall a couple days later (as I am going to do with Crysis 2) and have resigned themselves to not being able to change the gaming industry and its assumptions about players that defines fun" as one type of game play to the exclusion of all others.

The solution for me with Crysis 2 is to be able to have a slider to adjust the aliens

This way I can play the game with the level of challenge that keeps it fun for me

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game, it was done very well. The graphics are superb, and it overall a very lifelike experience. As far as gameplay goes, the game changes as you move forward. The more dynamic style keeps things interesting for you. At first when you have no upgrades and such, it's more of a cover-based shooter. However, as the game moves on, mele combat becomes more of the way forward. A few missions later when you have more upgrades, you become more of a tank, and can just mow over a lot of the people (of course they are kind enough to give you a gigantic boss at that point). Moving to the end it turns in to a more stealth shooter. All of this keeps you interested, and it's really enjoyable all the way through. There isn't much of a story, everything that can go wrong, goes wrong; and every time something goes wrong, you have to battle more people. That's pretty standard, but the story isn't really the focus of the game, so it doesn't matter that much.\n\nTL;DR: It's awesome.

reviewText: По-моему, отличный нью-йоркско-консольный дебют. Выглядит дорого и впечатляюще, развлекает по-разному. Опять же, американский мегаполис и перекрытые мосты — классика. И даже с иллюзией 3D в главном меню.\nПлюсы: красивейшие пейзажи; встроенное в движок 3D; вау-эффект; красочные закаты; динамика сетевого режима; тактические действия; командная игра.\nМинусы: мало оружия; плохо сбалансированные карты в мультиплеере; затянутость отдельных эпизодов кампании; нестабильность сетевого режима.

reviewText:
The plus side of this game, is that it's awesome. Graphics, sounds, action, and story are superb. I wish there was a little less action in places. It does get rather intense with full on action all the time. Not really a fully fledged grumble though coz I took breaks, and if you want to press on it's OK.

There isn't much I can say that reviews haven't covered about the game, like it's in the city. I can add that it doesn't suffer for not being set in a lush tropical paradise. The graphics are handled superbly. I pondered about lots looking around and taking in scenery, often crouching to look at even the ground. I loved all the different coloured rocks and pebbles they put in streams, that exist in real life. It's still a real vacation experience.

I have seen the odd complaint that it's possible to get through with little combat, and using stealth. Really though, why buy a shooter if you not going to fire your guns. The shooting action is epic too. You can go toe to toe with one standard enemy ground troop as you have better armour and better firepower.

I read criticism of the new nano-suit, and I think this is unfounded. It's much smoother to access. Maximum armour actually does something. With upgrades you add on during the game, it gets better.

All in all, a blockbuster from start to finish. Just maybe it could do with a little rest of easier gameplay once in a while.

reviewText:
Pros:

+ Stunning visual design that runs smooth and beautiful even on mid-range hardware (Crytek knows how to make a pretty engine)
+ Combat is fast-paced, exciting, and fun
+ Variety of weapons and suit-based powers only add to the range of combat experiences and play-styles
+ AI is solid

Cons:

- Story-line is mediocre
- Slight difficulty spikes
- Open-world" is more smoke and mirrors than actually sincere
- Managing suit-powers
recommended:
and engaging in combat can feel a little hectic for the control scheme

The Bottom Line

For me Crysis is a lot like Halo. While I'm not all that heavily invested in the franchise I still somewhow find myself buying and playing the games and continuing to do so despite coming away from each one with an overwhelming "meh" experience.

Crysis 2 is a lot of fun

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this is an epic first person shooter game, possibly one of the best I ever played.

Weapons are very well balanced and each have their own uses depending on your style. It also, like the original, has a great variety in the ways you can fight, either by stealth with cloak or by tanking through enemies with armor mode, the campaign is also a decent length, so you won't be beating it inside a couple of hours, though I could hardly see spending a total of 24 hours trying to beat the campaign. Regardless, the game excells in both gameplay and visuals, so even if you're one of those people who absolutely has to have that detail, this has it.

Now for the question, does this game continue directly off of the first?". No
recommended: at least not at first. Near the end the events that occurred between 1 and 2 are explained pretty well
hoursPlayed: so while you'll be left in the dark at first
voteText: you will get much more information later in the game. Which may feel like a drawback to some players
helpfulPercent: but I saw little issue with it

votesTotal: if nothing else
votesFunny: make it feel more interesting to find out what happened.\n\nAs for the story. While the game has a pretty thought-out story

reviewText:
Even though an untimely computer crash caused me not to be able to continue finishing the story mode, I have compiled a few thoughts about Crysis 2.
This game is pretty. Crytek went to the pretty store, bought everything in it, sprinkled extra pretty on top, then put it on sale. The best word in the arsenal of the english language to discribe the graphics is

stunning.

Even with my admitedly aging PC rig, I managed to have a very consistent, and enjoyable single player experience at 1080p resolution.  If I had a kidney to spare, I'd sell it for a PC that can run this game in all of its visual splendor, yet with my also admitedly meager funds and some careful configuring, found the PC version more satisfying than the xbox 360's.
The story and the in-game dialogue are a vast improvement over the first one, and the game itself sticks to tried and true FPS gameplay mechanics, without becoming tiresome. I was thoughly entertained from start to finish, and for the price of admission, hard to beat.

I reccomend this game with a 3/5,and 3.5/5 on sale.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewerDisplayName: All You Need is Dark Souls 3
reviewText:
I've put this game aside for now only because of saves. Any game, particularly on PC should allow you to save at any moment in your progress. Crysis 2, however, takes you back to your last check point. This increasing trend is extremely frustrating at times, and in Crysis 2 - where you can spend a significant amount of time getting past enemies - it is even moreso. Perhaps when I'm done clearing my massive backlog, I'll come back to it. But at this point in my life I'm more interested in quality time and a good story, than a game that intends on penalizing me with time loss thanks to the lack of a simple save function.

The story, is however, solid, and the graphics are beautiful. I'm somewhat disappointed by the lack of open world features, at least in comparison to the first Crysis, but it's understandable. Before it came out, I pictured being able to go into any building, or at least most buildings around you and exploring every location I could get into. That was a little unrealistic, I'll admit. Particularly when it was also a game designed with consoles in mind.

I recommend it, if you're looking for a good time waster.

reviewText:
Impressions & Score:

Story: 9.5 out of 10
The story in part II of Crysis has improved by a lot, although you do have a feeling that's copying Half-Life 2 on some aspects. There is a lot of work put into this new story, videos before every mission, information about characters and enemies, in-game cutscenes etc., most of the work is of good quality and there are some surprises throught the story, but not many. I liked how the aliens have been changed but at the same time I would have prefered to see a mix of old aliens and new ones, so that there's a logic why they changed aspect (they upgraded some of their units, etc.) otherwise you'll have the impression that there aren't the same as those from Crysis I, even though the story tries to tell you that they are. There are many captivating moments throught the story and I like the fact that it isn't too predictable, meaning that you won't know what will happen exactly. The end leaves room for many sequels to come, so be ready to continue buying Crysis.

Graphics: 10 out of 10
Crysis 2 continues it's legacy of excellent graphics that it started in 2007, improving on every aspect. The lights, weapon effects, character design, environments are all top notch, the only thing I'm dissapointed is the fact that they removed vehicule interiors, which were not only great in the first Crysis but gave more realism to the game. There are some bad graphics on certain objects, but you'll ignore them easily  when you evaluate the whole game. Crysis 2 graphics still manage to impress me and I'm playing this game in 2015, so that's why I gave it the maximum score.

Gameplay: 8 out of 10
Gameplay is great, many features added (ledge grab, power kick, combined nano powers etc.) but other were removed (vehicule interiors - which would have been great on the streets of New York, no flight vehicules, no boats, no tanks, no freezing effect etc.). Some removed features, I can understand, others not, since they would have made the gameplay better. Also, I've mentioned earlier the bug with some spawn locations, which can remove some realism from the game.  The good thing is that some of the features added work very well, in the ruined New York environment. Many players complained for the fact that the game became too linear, you don't have the freedom to roam around on huge map like in Crysis 1, but I understand the producers for making the game more linear, since many of the cool effects (buildings, bridges falling etc.) wouldn't have been possible on a  free-roam map, also the level of details wouldn't have been the same. Overall the gameplay is quite cool when combined with the great story.

Audio: 10 out of 10
The music in Crysis 2 is just awesome, especially the music in the menu, the other sound effects are also of high quality. How can I give it less than 10 when sometimes I was starting the game just to listen the music, I wasn't even playing.

AI Behavior: 8.5 out of 10
The AI is quite good, not awesome, but it handles itself pretty well. I've played the game on the max difficulty (Post-Human Warrior) and I didn't find the game too hard, the AI shoots very well but if you use corectly the nanosuit powers, you'll manage to finish each mission after just a few tries (you'll need a few, since the enemies are unpredictable).  The Human AI soldiers will try to flank you and use grenades, while the Aliens AI will jump on you, deactivate your suit and even cloak (at end of the game). The bad part is that sometimes the AI acts stupid, for example you kill an enemy AI on cloak right in front of his friends and they don't react at all, like nothing happened. Also sometimes the AI gets stucked behind certain boxes or in certain areas. Over 75 % of my kills were stealth kills (mostly with the knife), actually if you play on the max difficulty, most of your kills will be stealth also, since the enemy can kill you easily even with armor mode on. Still even after those bugs, the AI is quite good and dynamic, for which it deserves a good score.

Multiplayer: not tested
I've played this game during a month that I had no internet at all, so I couldn't actually test anything that involved multiplayer. But I've red that the suits powers are diminished considerably, in order to be able to kill other players faster, and not wander around in a stalemate. I'm not a multiplayer gamer, so I mostly prefer single-player campaigns, but I think that Crysis 2 would have deserved at least an 8 or a 9 for the multiplayer (mostly because of many removed features).

Overall: 9.2 out 10
The new Crysis 2, really improves on everything that the last one did except gameplay. I didn't gave the maximum score because I didn't liked the fact that they removed a lot of cool stuff from the previous Crysis, like a lot of vehicules and boats and other things. But even after this Crysis 2 definitely is worth the money, the story is very well done for a shooter, you'll spend many hours of good gameplay, the environments are awesome, the aliens are great, the audio is cool, what more can I say. I bought the game on a sale for less than 4 EUR, but if you don't want to wait for a sale, go and buy it right away cause it deserves full price.

PS:
Enemies in Crysis do have the same amount of health and deal the same amount of damage regardless of difficulty. Difficulty only affects their A.I.; i.e. reaction time, awareness, accuracy, and duration of burst fire.
On the highest difficulty setting(Post-Human Warrior there's no split-second invincibility after you're hit, allowing you to be damaged by each consecutive bullet in a spray of automatic fire. As a result, you die a LOT faster against automatic fire when not in Armor Mode. In Armor Mode, however, your durability seems pretty much the same. Source: gamefaqs.com/Crysis 2 Weapons-Enemies Guide

Important: After finishing the game I only got 12 out 13 weapons attachments, which gave me a 99.76 % completion. I was a bit disappointed that I couldn't get 100 % completion and started to look online for tips. I found out that you actually cannot get the 13 weapons attachments because of a bug (they decided that ironsights isn't an attachment, but then they forget to update the list to contain 12 not 13) that the producers forgot to remove, so at least try to get at least 12 if you want to have the game completed 100 %.


Obs: The only thing I dislike about the new Crysis 2 is the enemy predefined spawn locations, which are really annoying at first and predictable after that. Example: I have to destroy a fuel supply, after the fuel supply explodes, enemies start to spawn in predefined locations (some spawns are good, those when the enemy comes from outside the map, others are just awfull, like when the enemy spawn right in front of you, this removes some part of realism from the game). By the way, the AI is great, not very smart but dynamic, which makes every encounter different.

Story: 9.5 out of 10

There is a lot of work put into this new story, videos before every mission, information about characters and enemies, in-game cutscenes etc., most of the work is of good quality and there are some surprises throught the story, but not many. I liked how the aliens have been changed but at the same time I would have prefered to see a mix of old aliens and new ones, so that there's a logic why they changed aspect (they upgraded some of their units, etc.) otherwise you'll have the impression that there aren't the same as those from Crysis I, even though the story tries to tell you that they are. There are many captivating moments throught the story and I like the fact that it isn't too predictable, meaning that you won't know what will happen exactly. reviewText:
First of all this is kind of a pointless to review such a game which is critically acclaimed by everyone (literally) and secondly, I have completed the game pretty late - considering the time of release of the game.

But these being said, I feel that I should put my thoughts for this awe-inspiring game at least once.

So, I have broken down my thought or review(so to speak) in sections -

Story: The plot is very thick - though it may not have the emotional content that we can find in the popular CoD series of games. But still the plot compels  the player to stick to the game and hear out the different chatters between the NPCs. The link up with the 1st installment of this series is very smooth and now it all make sense". Still I would have loved to have at-least a couple of side missions / sub-plots in the game (specially when these days when FPS leverage some of the RPG elements).

Gameplay: Very smooth indeed; the keyboard configuration is very nice and also be dragged to the multiplayer games without changing much -  in fact I played the multiplayer with default keyboard and mouse config. The movements are very nice and the transitions between nano suit modes are seamless. You could just put on some strength just before shooting your sniper rifle and then just after the shot switch to cloak without any difficulty. Cut Scenes are very nicely played and well placed

Graphics : well when you are talking about a game that uses Cry Engine 3 "Graphics" is the most spectacular feature that you wish to review. in words - STUNNING!! I have made a few in game snaps that I wish to keep forever. the horizon and the urban landscapes are too good and the NY city is realistically portrayed here. Since I used a bit older GTX 570 to play the game- I had to reduce a bit of the quality in order to get an optimum performance. Still
recommended:
you will feel that a new world is coming alive in front of your eyes.

Multiplay - well the MP is really really good (once you get used to the pace and skills) and I earned a few badges there. Unfortunately I had to stop the MP cause it was interfering with my CS 1.6 skills (whatever I have left of it) cause their game mechanics are completely different..

So in shorter words - I really liked that game - so much
hoursPlayed:
that I played the campaign in 2 different difficulty modes. If you are looking for some FPS with gripping story and stunning graphics with smooth gameplay then be sure that you have this game in your library.

And thanks to steam that I got it in much cheaper rate.

- Maximum Game -"

reviewText:
This is a console port.  I loved Crysis and Crysis Warhead, but this was like biting into a piece of poop.

Crysis and Crysis Warhead put you into deceptively open environments.  It was linear, but allowed you freedom.  This was done fantastically.  You could run and jump around, and come at tasks from different angles and accomplish them in different ways.  You were changing armor modes and doing fun stuff the entire game.  Sneaking in, sneaking out.  Running in, grabbing a guy, running out, then throwing him off a cliff.  Sneaking in, taking over a machine gun, then switching to armor mode and using the gun.  There was flanking, stealth, open environments, vehicles, etc etc etc.  It was a truely great FPS.

Crysis 2 is Crysis 1 with dumbed down graphics, dumbed down armor (you just use armor mode the entire game), infinite ammunition, no free roam environments, never an enemy 50 yards away, full body hitboxes (no headshots), stupid-as-♥♥♥♥ story line, and was clearly just a money grab.  It's like they took Crysis and said Hey
date: how can we make the sequel the same as Call of Duty
recommended: but with the hitboxes of an RPG?"\n\nThere are no decisions to be made.  You just trudge forward
hoursPlayed: blazing your gun the entire time in armor mode.  Enemies spawn like a Gauntlet game.  You kill one
voteText: and another identical one just pops out from the same location.  Each area has 5-20 guys that you kill like this.  The enemies aren't human
helpfulPercent: they're robots.  Because they explain that the aliens are all wearing suits like yours now.  So every fight is blasting into the enemy 50 or so times until it dies and is immediately replaced by its clone.\n\nAlso
votesHelpful: the AI got worse.  The enemy never works as a team.  I find it strange that they did this.  Maybe XBOX's processor couldn't handle the old AI?  I don't know."

reviewText:
Better than its predecessor and certainly more compatible with Windows 8 and 64 bit systems, Crysis 2 is proof that a game can never be too finished. The new functions of the HUD, namely the ability to tag objects, use thermal vision and navigate the environment in more inventive ways than before, all add a great new dimension to the Crysis universe. The setting of New York is very well recreated. The crisis of the aliens invasion is masterfully plotted and the introduction in which you and your squad members have to swim to saftey, only to be rendered unconscious by an unknown enemy, sets the stage for a compelling adventure.

The  weapons are as modern, diverse and advanced as ever. They make you think that all soldiers of the future should adopt them. The AI is no pushover and will give you a run for your money. The physics of the various impacts are well researched, impressive and fun to see. You will find at least a handful of ways to take the enemy on and have a good laugh.

Crytek  created a great followup in the form of Crysis 2. The extras also add extra replayability, so, if you have the means and love Crytek games, get this one. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Better than its predecessor and certainly more compatible with Windows 8 and 64 bit systems, Crysis 2 is proof that a game can never be too finished. The new functions of the HUD, namely the ability to tag objects, use thermal vision and navigate the environment in more inventive ways than before, all add a great new dimension to the Crysis universe. The setting of New York is very well recreated. The crisis of the aliens invasion is masterfully plotted and the introduction in which you and your squad members have to swim to saftey, only to be rendered unconscious by an unknown enemy, sets the stage for a compelling adventure.

The  weapons are as modern, diverse and advanced as ever. They make you think that all soldiers of the future should adopt them. The AI is no pushover and will give you a run for your money. The physics of the various impacts are well researched, impressive and fun to see. You will find at least a handful of ways to take the enemy on and have a good laugh.

Crytek  created a great followup in the form of Crysis 2. The extras also add extra replayability, so, if you have the means and love Crytek games, get this one. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
First of all this is kind of a pointless to review such a game which is critically acclaimed by everyone (literally) and secondly, I have completed the game pretty late - considering the time of release of the game.

But these being said, I feel that I should put my thoughts for this awe-inspiring game at least once.

So, I have broken down my thought or review(so to speak) in sections -

Story: The plot is very thick - though it may not have the emotional content that we can find in the popular CoD series of games. But still the plot compels  the player to stick to the game and hear out the different chatters between the NPCs. The link up with the 1st installment of this series is very smooth and now it all make sense". Still I would have loved to have at-least a couple of side missions / sub-plots in the game (specially when these days when FPS leverage some of the RPG elements).

Gameplay: Very smooth indeed; the keyboard configuration is very nice and also be dragged to the multiplayer games without changing much -  in fact I played the multiplayer with default keyboard and mouse config. The movements are very nice and the transitions between nano suit modes are seamless. You could just put on some strength just before shooting your sniper rifle and then just after the shot switch to cloak without any difficulty. Cut Scenes are very nicely played and well placed

Graphics : well when you are talking about a game that uses Cry Engine 3 "Graphics" is the most spectacular feature that you wish to review. in words - STUNNING!! I have made a few in game snaps that I wish to keep forever. the horizon and the urban landscapes are too good and the NY city is realistically portrayed here. Since I used a bit older GTX 570 to play the game- I had to reduce a bit of the quality in order to get an optimum performance. Still
recommended:
you will feel that a new world is coming alive in front of your eyes.

Multiplay - well the MP is really really good (once you get used to the pace and skills) and I earned a few badges there. Unfortunately I had to stop the MP cause it was interfering with my CS 1.6 skills (whatever I have left of it) cause their game mechanics are completely different..

So in shorter words - I really liked that game - so much
hoursPlayed:
that I played the campaign in 2 different difficulty modes. If you are looking for some FPS with gripping story and stunning graphics with smooth gameplay then be sure that you have this game in your library.

And thanks to steam that I got it in much cheaper rate.

- Maximum Game -"

reviewText:
Everything feels like it should be right with this game. You have stealth capabilities, armor, you can quickly change weapon mods on the fly, you can scan your surroundings and look for helpful things. You're a badass black ops nano super soldier dude, and it should be great. But it isn't.

Nothing comes together right. I've played a lot of stealth games, and the stealth encounters in this game rarely work out right. People notice you from far away and then all hell breaks loose and all you really have to do is activate your armor, shoot at the bad guys for a few seconds and then hide to recharge your armor. You can go stealth again but it's all going to go back to chaos in the next minute anyway.

And that's what the gun fights are like: chaos. It doesn't feel tactical or fun, enemies just seem to spawn out of nowhere, and you mow them down until the game decides to not spawn enemies for a while. Your choice of weapons are limited and there really isn't that big of a difference between them for the most part. You've got shooty rifle, fast shooty rifle, and far away shooty rifle. Also there's a shotgun and maybe a couple handguns. Who cares? They all feel equally unsatisfying to use.

Then there's the tiny frustrations. The game showing an objective on the roof, and so you walk to the stairwell door and you press F to open. It doesn't. OK I'll melee it open. Doesn't budge. Maybe it's locked I'll power kick it because I'm in a ♥♥♥♥ing super suit. Nope, the door's content to just stay closed. Apparently in this game you don't use doors. Doors just really aren't a thing. Turns out I was actually supposed to jump out the window. Which is fitting because that's what I felt like doing anyway.

Then at the very beginning after a ten minute intro you finally get to play. So I'm walking around and I see it let's me activate a laptop, so I do and a recording starts playing. It's a discussion that reveals some backstory, so I go on my way and walk up the steps, but the sound of the recording fades. What? In the first minute of gameplay you're going to tether me to a single room where I can do nothing but listen to a recording that I don't know how long it is? And if I leave, I miss the backstory. Stupid stupid stupid stupid.

And then there's was a, not a cutscene because it didn't cut, but a live scene I guess? Where you can walk around while another character is talking? One of those, and during this scene the other character is like here look on this screen at all this exposition about the story" but I couldn't walk past his couch to look at the screen directly. There was just an arbitrary invisible wall keeping me from going over there. And then the bad guys attack the apartment and my gun pops up like I should be able to use it
date: and there's a objective telling me to kill the bad guys
recommended: but it won't let me shoot out the window at the like five snipers across the way! I'm mashing the fire button but nothing's happening! No
hoursPlayed:
the game doesn't want me to fight there. It wants me to go out into the hallway and fight through the building. Nothing about this is good.

I'm sick and tired of games sticking me in a room where all I can do is listen to a guy who's showing me ♥♥♥♥ on another screen telling me the story. This is the opposite of the one of the fundamentals of storytelling which is "show don't tell."

If you buy this game
voteText: you're in for disappointment
helpfulPercent: because it looks like it's going to be so fun
votesHelpful: but it just fails at every turn. Don't waste your time.\n\n"

Its OK for a modern FPS.
