reviewText:
With Crysis 2, the series finally arrived where it was always meant to be. Crysis 2 is the equivalent of the loud, obnoxious blockbuster movie dazzling the audience with its fancy effects. Hell, they even got Hans Zimmer to do the soundtrack.

That being said, despite cutting down a lot on the open world aspect, Crysis 2 is probably a better game than the original. At least this one has something resembling proper pacing. The game does a far better job alternating between quiet moments, full-on shootouts and everything in-between. It also throws the player into a couple of memorable scenarios instead of making him infiltrate the same military base over and over again. The gunplay is also improved as it finally has some weight to it and the recoil doesn't seem that random anymore.

However, not all areas have been improved upon. The enemy design, for instance, is actually a step back since you're mostly fighting aliens who look like oversized (human) grunts with squishy heads - the predecessor's design definitely looked and felt more 'alien'.

The story is still completely irrelevant and only serves as an excuse to drag the player through different setpieces. And yet, the game feels the need pester you with radio chatter and cutscenes regularly even though it neither cares about the characters it introduces nor the story it was supposed to tell.

Despite some improvements, Crysis 2 is still lackluster. Although I did enjoy some parts of the game and the scenery of a war-torn New York does have a certain draw to it, a first person shooter that features subpar gunplay is simply not that enjoyable. It doesn't help that the opportunities to use various suit powers have been drastically reduced.

Even if it fails at everything else, the game is a competent benchmark to torture your GPU with.

reviewText:
*Sigh* What a disappointment. Let's keep this to the points. Crysis 2 is a bad game. Crysis 1 and Warhead are better and worth spending on. Why is Crysis 1 / Warhead better? Well, because it has the following:

A semi-large open sandbox environment.
Being able to go Prone (snake belly on the floor shuffle).
Better control over Nanosuit abilities (able to activate strength mode, speed mode at will rather having it on by default)
More ability to be stealthy and favour a silent approach.
A whooole newww worllllld... a fantaaastic poiiiint of viiiiewwww. It was a new experience.

Crysis 2 shoves you down a corridoor shooter under the pretense of being an open world sandbox environment. You are tricked into thinking it is, but it's not. It's a lie. The game features stupid setpieces, fixed cutscenes that no one cares about, a storyline as farfetched and uninteresting as it can be and a linear progression which renders you bored and tired.

Yes, the visuals are amazing but the whole game experience is such a farce that I don't think it's worth you sitting through the whole title. Go play Crysis 1 and Warhead (expansion). Those are brilliant games. Very enjoyable. VERY.

Avoid Crysis 2. Please. Crysis 3 is even worse than Crysis 2. Crytek don't know how to make games. Just expensive tech demos and benchmark tools which take up 20GB of your HDD / SDD and give you nothing in return but railroad boredom.

reviewText:
All around Console Port CRAP, THERE'S NOT EVEN A PRONE.

I went from play crysis having the most fun I have had in a SP game in years to this crap. Irritating game controls that dose not play much like the Original(mostly the crappy Lean left and right and no prone that pisses me off).The quick suit menu is in a diffrent order and going right from crysis to this I'm use to that and keep picking the wrong option.Not a big deal but come on keep it consistant so when people move right from the last game to this it feels familiar.

I do like the dedacated buttons for suit options though, just hit a key for cloak or armor.

Lean left and right are worthless, you use your mouse to lean when you aim down sight by a wall, What the hell MORE CONSOLE LEFTOVER CRAP.

(after play for a bit of time I'm a little use to this and at times it has its merits. You can peak over stuff with more precision then just going from crouching to standing but for leaning left and right it's still not as good as the original game).

No quick save just check points. More leftover CONSOLE CRAP (I can deal with this but sometimes I need to go do other things and then I have to leave the game going or lose my progression).

This next thing bugs me the most.

At times you can't even look where you want to, the game forces you to look at what they want you too see or the suit goes into tactical override and tells you how to turn on the cloak or armor mode like your some fool. This kind of crap ruins replay value for me,eveytime I play the game it going to tell me how to play the game, I DON'T LIKE THAT. And the prompts that tell you what key you need to use to do stuff clutter the screen as I'm trying to play.(and theres no option to turn that off)

I want to feel like I'm there, not watching through someone else's eyes or being babysat and told what to do.I could understand it maybe telling you how to use the suit if your playing on the easiest difficulty but I went right for the hardest and don't need any damn help.I Have been playing FPS games since I was ten.

I dont usually make reviews but this games lack of a good lean and prone and handholding sucks so I had to rant about it somewhere.Even the video settings lack options like anti aliasing, something you expect in any modern game.

The game looks good, that's the only nice thing I have to say about it, It is what Diablo 3 is to Diablo 2.A let down.Not the worst sequal but not what I wanted or was expecting.

I may be a bit over critical because I absolutely hate how consoles are dumbing down gaming, And there is no reason for it.JUST MAKE THE GAMES FOR PC AND PORT THEM TO CONSOLE AND EVERYONE WILL BE HAPPY.They might lose stuff, but they are not likely to complan about it because thats how it has to be to work on there console systems, but it dosent need to be that way on PC.

After getting use to all the CONSOLE CRAP this game has, I Am having fun. But cannot recommend this game becaus it would be promoting the degradation of good PC gaming.

Edit:Now that I have completed the game I can say It was fun and the story was not bad.

Though the aliens are nothing like the first game and the ones from the first game do not make a appearance(thay are the same aliens but the squid like exoskeletons from the first are not in this one).

If you gave the game another name and renamed the few people that are taken form the first game you would have another game just with the same nanosuit not really a sequel.Not really a bad thing per se, just seems odd to me.

Still I feel it was a degradation of what could have been a better PC game. I got it for free when my brother got me the humble bundle. Having played it now I would not want to have payed more then $5 for it.

reviewText:
This game Improved many things over Crysis.

But overwall, it was a good game. Haven't played much Multiplayer yet.

A few things i didn't like:
- Cutscenes aren't skipable, which is annoying, mostly on 2nd and 3rd playthroughs.
- You uncloak if you go for a Stealth Kill, which shouldn't happen (at least in Campaign).
- Sometimes, enemies can see you even while you're cloaked and you're not by them.


But overwall, it was a good game. Haven't played much Multiplayer yet.

reviewText: A wonderful masterpiece that is well worth your time. Crysis 2 is a game that is a worthy successor to the massively acclaimed Crysis. With masterful graphics, and revamped gameplay, Crysis 2 is a work of art all on its own. With the included threat of the Ceph, the pesky Koreans from the last Crysis seem like baby toys, with high tech weaponry and deadly technology, you feel like you are a god among men when you are mowing these aliens down. But one of the largest changes that impressed me is how the nanosuit interface has changed. Crysis 2 has made the usage of the nanosuit a lot more user friendly, so instead of having to use your mouse wheel to select certain armor abilities in Crysis, you press key binds to use them, and in some cases they are used on their own without having to activate it. Like instead of selecting sprint to run super-fast, now regular sprint does that automatically for you, and to use your enhanced jumping, you just hold space instead of switching to strength then jumping. It makes the suit a lot more functional and easier to use. With an excellent story to continue the originally Crysis. I don’t feel it is worth the $30 price tag, but if you can find it on sale, this game is a wonderful game. Just make sure to play the original Crysis first, because a lot of the background story in the first in necessary to understand the story in Crysis 2.

reviewText:
After only a few hours on the books I can already tell how Crysis 2 will play.  If you were or currently are, a fan of the first crysis with its open level design and AI then DO NOT buy Crysis 2 unless its on sale for 7 bucks.

This is a nearly a completely linear corridor shooter from the beginning to where I am now.  The graphics are very nice, but you can tell that crytek built this with consoles in mind.  The levels are short and contained.  Nothing open at all.  The scripted segments are cliche and overused.  Large exploding scenes are coupled with overacted dialogue and tired performances.  Its your basic run of the mil fps with pretty graphics.  The multiplayer I have not touched, nor will I ever touch since EA is bringing down the servers pretty soon.

All i can say in the end is, if you're a fan of the COD single player expeirence then buy Crysis 2.  The campaign isn't terrible, it's just been done before.  If you're a fan of open world shooters like farcry and the first Crysis then prepare to be dissapointed.

reviewText:
This game is NOT worth the asking price of 30$ You get extra junk in a dead multiplayer mode, and a completely broken game. If you really want to pick it up, for whatever reason, I strongly suggest waiting for a sale, you will regret buying this for its full price.
Positive - -

It's a crisis game, the gunplay is tight and responsive, when it works, and the nanosuit is still a lot of fun to play with, I appreciate the simpler control mechanics, and merging maximum speed and strength into the core functions, making combat more fluid. Instead of the old modes you are given a cloak and maximum armor toggles.

While more linear than the original, the map layouts have various routes the player can take to flank, ambush or just bypass certain enemies, giving you enough options to suit most playstyles.

Weapon choices are varied and fun, giving you something for any engagement and some fun variations like the K-volt Taser" SMG
date: a suppressed pump action shotgun and plenty of customization for each.\n\nThe story is engaging
recommended: and kept me interested throughout the sections I have played through
hoursPlayed:
roughly halfway into the game. Would you like to know more? I do!

Negative - -

Having reached the half point of the game

column18: which makes taking the stealth route very tedious and frustrating.\n\nFurthermore immersion is broken on a regular basis by malfunctioning AI constantly spamming their voice dialogues

column20: Crytek. The original game was hard on the computer

reviewText:
Here I thought I wouldn't be putting a negative review of this game considering how  crysis 1 went, but here it is.  What some see as the negative to the suit changes, I found refreshing, and the fact they fixed the bugs/gltiches are the only positive marks I can give this game.

They completely got rid of any kind of open play, small areas at a time to navigate, ok I guess I did like the alien AI, I thought they did a good job with that, flanking, jumping barriers, retreating, advancing, and trying to locate sounds and anti-stealth counter-measures.

Sorry but this game didn't feel like a shooter to me, far to few enemies, not enough variety, I believe in total there where 5 types of enemies, 2 version of grunts, one gun one melee, semi-cloak guy, the heavy infrantry type guy and the big robot guy which there is only 2 or 3 of thoes.  And the steath guys at the end which is only 4 of them.  I maybe had to fire a couple hundred rounds if I felt like it, but the stealth and easy kills and bashing was far to easy.

Something about this game just made me say blah, it's already uninstalled and most likely will never get played again, I usually enjoy going back and playing the better shooters, I don't think I'll be revisting this one.

Nothing in this game made me care about the story or the characters, felt rushed and pushed, no options, I enjoyed crysis 1 and I thought they had a good thing going, they had a good shooter a good story, just needed to fine tune it, but what they did is the fix the bugs, but also broke everything that was good about the first game.

reviewText: The best New-York based alien invasion you will likely ever play through. While it deviates quite a bit from Crysis 1, Crysis 2 still offers the same nanosuit-based kickassery. Don't worry about the story either, it's confusing at first but all adds together with a little thought. Most of the plot holes left by Crysis 2 are patched up in Crysis 3, and ultimately end up making the entire series a lot more interesting narratively.\n\nThe game is also simply gorgeous, as a staple of the Crysis franchise. Crysis 1 and 3 are arguably more gorgeous though.

Mean Mr. Mustard's short Crysis 2 - Maximum Edition review

1) Essential - buy it NOW
2) Recommended - buy it on sale
3) Avoid
Time to complete – 7 hours
Played multiplayer? No
Worth revisiting? No, typical modern-day FPS

Worst part – Safe, generic, boring. Crysis 2 offers nothing new

reviewText:
Forget what i said down below. EA and their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t decided to shut down all the multiplayer servers and refuses to make any sort of statement as to what they plan to do, and any sort of player-made workarounds, even ones that require a purchased copy of the game, are being labled as copyright infringement by EA.

If you want it for a cool singleplayer, fine, but don't pay much more than what I did. It's just not worth it anymore.

--------
Gorgeous visuals, nearly pushing my Super-Jesus gaming rig to it's limits when on Ultra settings. Brilliant combat mechanics, immersive and engaging storyline, extremely fun multiplayer (although it would be much nicer if little kids weren't constantly screaming that anybody better than them is a hacker).

I bought this for $7.49 from Steam, and dammit, i would have paid 10 times that for this game.

GET IT.

reviewText:
Mix Halo games with Half-Life, add some basic weapon customization and you have Crysis 2, with better graphics.
It feels pretty cookie-cutter and rather linear as far as storyline and gameplay goes. It gives you a sense of choice in how you accomplish a task, but in the end, it really comes down to the gunning and shooting.

It's not a bad game - however it's not much more than a technical demo for the Crytek engine.

reviewText: A real piece-of-stinking-crap-game that should be offensive to anyone of average or above intelligence. It starts with an absurdly long cutscene that doesn't bring any useful information to the player except that the developers believe that big explosions and shiny graphics will make you interested in this turd of a game. It's broken up by masked cutscenes in the actual engine where you are able to look around, as if they think you're stupid enough that this miniscule form of interactivity would make you feel less like you're watching a dumb action movie about big explosions. And it just keeps dragging on to the point where I started feeling like the purpose was to bore you to death.\n\nWhat follows is probably the worst case of constricting hand-holding I've ever seen. They constantly take the control away from the player in order to ensure you don't miss their super cool and awesome scripted events". As with the interactive cutscenes they make you unable to move
date: you cannot continue playing until you do what the game prompts you to.\n\nBy the time I was about to start in on the actual gameplay I was so frustrated at the game that I could not bare to continue. It took some 20 minutes to get that far
recommended: 20 minutes which were so poor on actual useful information that it could easily have been cut down to about two minutes
hoursPlayed: with some time left for filler explosions to make you realise how cool of a game the developers think they've created. Poor game design all over. Absolute garbage. The end."
voteText: December 20, 2013

reviewText: When this first came out in 2011 I had paid full price for it after being allowed to test it in closed beta multiplayer then open beta because it was pure awesome. I beat the SP, and put close to if not more than 100 hours in MP. The cloaking abilities have been copied by other games but no other games can quite get the full magic of this game. Every aspect of the game is good, from sounds to weapons to enemies to mission structure, if only a bit linear. I doubt you will find any multiplayer games going anymore, otherwise this is for sure worth getting on sale for a fun time playing through sp.

reviewText: The game itself is actually pretty well made. The gameplay is fluid and familiar to people who play Halo, but still relatively close to players of CoD, giving it a nice mix between somewhat slow paced shooters and fast twitch shooters. reviewText:
This is a teen's FPS/stealth with its scenario, length and style.  It was as I expected from the comments.

The goods are obviously the graphics, game options (combat/stealth) which is clearly identified with visor and not too complicated and few guns and suit options.  I really liked that you don't have to waste time looking around loots or go through tons of secrets.  The collectibles you can definitely skip with nothing to miss.

The negatives are the length of the game with max 15 hours (maximum edition?? - but then again, short game is good so that you don't waste time), AI (silly enemies),  easy play in stealth, not too useful guns and suit options. The game says 'be weapon' where you cloak around all the way :)

I didn't play the first and probably will not play the third.  It wasn't bad, I don't regret it - like RAGE or Deadspace for example, but it was OK for $5.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I definately enjoyed this game. the graphics were beautiful, the AIs were decently hard, and the gameplay mechanics were very fun. I really liked the tactics approach to the game. Stealth is enjoyable, armor makes you feel badass, and some of the weapons were just plain awesome.
My main complaint is the voice acting. Some of the characters *cough* Gould *cough* didn't sound very convincing, and at several times throughout the game the audio clips didn't match up to what was happening. Also, some guns are basically useless on higher difficulties, and on the flipside this game throws in too many (in my opinion) HMGs for you to use.
Don't even try it if you don't have a good computer.
This game is a beast.
85/100

reviewText:
i didn't expect it. but crysis 2 is a gem. Normally i dislike modern millitary shooters like cod and battlefield, but crysis has a very unique style. the graphics are still amazing, the soundtrack is very well done, the story is exiting, and there are even small BOSS-BATTLES! (the walker thingy's and the gun helicopter)

-sometimes the A.I. does unintentionally funny stuff which can get you out of the experience, but overal its a 9/10.

PLUS there is just something magical about hearing 'MAXIMUM ARMOUR', before storming a helpless army, that makes you feel like a futuristic half-god.

MULTIPLAYER IS OFFLINE, BUT THIS IS STILL A GOLDEN GAME!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I know this game was praised as a graphical masterpiece when it was released and it still holds up extremely well as a benchmark for your rig.  It's vibrant with tons of effects and well textured throughout even if certain assets are reused over and over again (some of it can be immersion breaking but I thought think you're here for the roleplaying aspect anyway).

It's a solid FPS experience with hours of content unlike the modern day shooters you see with a few hours, the campaign definitely felt lengthy and the storyline present.  The plot isn't something to write to your mother about but it's passable for the genre and even had a few memorable characters (though lots of blank ones too).

The gameplay itself offers lots of variance in tackling objectives while spoonfeeding you certain ones using the Objective scanner" by pushing B.  While helpful at times so it's clear what you have to do
date:
some of this definitely took a lot of the challenge away and feelings of accomplishment on completing any objective or entire mission.

Some of Prophet's abilities are a bit too strong as well such as Stealthing (which seems to be a common complaint among players) that it takes too much of the challenge away from the game but with the Ceph enemies using EMP pulses and the like - I found just enough variance and challenge to enjoy the experience.  It 'will' get repetitive to an extent but it overall was a pleasant experience with a large enough variance in weapons and secondaries.

The A.I. is one of the few complaitns I have with the game - sometimes the enemies were buggy and multiple times during the playthrough - I found them clipped or stuck on terrain (especially the Heavy Ceph).  While this meant they were exploitable in a game that already felt a bit too easy.  Other times the enemies (especially Ceph) would just randomly patrol/pace back and forth while you were shooting at them - as if they were trying to decide if they should fight back or run away.

Overall I wouldn't say it's a must-play game release but it didn't have enough shortcomings for me to warn people away from the experience if they are a fan of futuristic-tech FPS campaigns."

reviewText:
Gameplay
For me, the gameplay in Crysis 2 is wayyy better than Crysis and Crysis Warhead. You can be more agile and plan your tatics faster. The maps are small, but the emotion is great.
What I liked the most is tha AI. The AI in Crysis 2 is more intelligent than the previous AIs.

I am not saying that Crysis and Crysis Warhead sucks, actually they are great. However, for me, Crysis 2 is greater.

I don't know what kind of magic did they use in this game but, the graphics are awesome. The game is better optimized than the others.

History
About the history, you will assume the control of a Marine named Alcatraz, who gains ownership of the nanosuit from Prophet. CryNet Systems has been hunting Prophet to take the suit back, but they don't know that actually Prophet has given the suit to Alcatraz.

I recommend you to finish Crysis and Crysis Warhead before getting into Crysis 2, so you can understand better the history.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Another Crysis must play
Crysis is one of the best single player FPS ever released, if not the best, and expectations for Crysis 2 are pretty high. Having played the first game intensively I was excited about the second game and I was not left disappointed.

Graphics
Very realistic
Very detailed textures
Great lightingSound
Epic soundtrack
Weapons sound very good
Very good voice actingBalance
Difficulties all extremely well balanced
Play as fast as you want to - if you want to finish a level fast, you can
Game helps you with tactics if you  needAtmosphere
Real places
Amazing cut scenes in player view instead of loading a video
Most areas have no humans in them whatsoever, they're simply empty and yet you are told at one point that the city is full with people, really?UI
Nano-suit extremely easy to use and get  used to
Not able to save whenever you wantContent
Pretty long single-player for a FPS
You can replay the game since there are different ways of solving missions
CollectablesLevel design
Detailed levels
The levels are very diverse, sometimes you're underground, in sewers, in buildings or streets
Some levels are longAI
Take cover
Call for assistance
Not many different types of enemies, soldiers or aliens and there's only 2-3 types of aliensWeapons
Extremely interesting nano suit concept
Weapons can be modified
Able to upgrade nanosuit
Some of the upgrades don't make sense in the single playerStory
Great start
Allies keep changing
Sadly no real final but rather a cliff-hanger for the next game
ConclusionCrysis was an amazing game and so is Crysis 2. Unfortunately it is not as good as the first game and yet it still is a game that really anyone needs to play. If you can lower your expectations from the first game you will see that this is an epic game with great game play but also story and even addicting soundtrack.

I would recommend this game to literally anyone even if they don't actually enjoy FPS games. Crysis 2 is very different and excels at so many things that it is difficult to even compare it to the average FPS. The  nano suit is an experience in itself while the story will make anyone curious. It does not matter whether you have experience with FPS or not as the easiest difficulty literally allows you to sprint through levels while barely shooting anyone. I have finished this game within around 7 hours but admit ignoring a lot of enemies or using stealth to avoid lengthy fights. If you are a fan of Crysis then you can safely purchase this game.

This game was played at maximum settings on this system:
Monitor: BenQ XL2420T[www.amazon.co.uk]
GPU: Sapphire Tri-X R9 290[www.scan.co.uk]
CPU: Intel Core i5-4670[www.amazon.co.uk]
RAM: Kingston HyperX Blu 4x4[www.amazon.co.uk]
Motherboard: MSI Z87-G45
SSD: Samsung SSD 830[www.amazon.co.uk]

If you have any further questions or are still unsure if you should buy it feel free to ask.

reviewText: Fun game, but a few things confused me in regards to the invisibility suit power. When you're invisible, the enemies naturally can't see you; that's fine. However, your shadow is clearly still there and you would make noise when you move, the enemies don't seem to pick up on that. One more point, the throat slashing stealth kill I'm a little sceptical about. Unless with that stab you managed to cut through their spinal cord, they wouldn't die instantly. Simply cutting arteries isn't enough to ensure instant death, they'd be bleeding for a lot longer than the time that was allowed.\n\nFun, buy it if you want.

reviewText: Decent but plodding.  Enemies are unusually tough, requiring sniper rifle headshots, stealth kills, or a steady stream of bullets to dispatch.  You move relatively slowly, too.  Graphics were nice enough in terms of realism but they had no emotional punch like those in Bioshock Infinite.  Crysis 2 does not seem to have any replay value.  However, the game is probably still worth playing at a heavily discounted price.\n\n(Just started playing the original Crysis and, wow, it seems much more fun.  Faster movement and kills, feels more free to roam around.  You can drive boats!)
